Hey! I‚Äôm Sasha, nice to meet you! Over the next two weeks, I‚Äôll be exploring healthy and sustainable eating with you.

A year ago, I started eating more plant-based foods and learned a lot along the way. It‚Äôs not about being perfect; I don‚Äôt think we all need to go completely vegan. But being a bit mindful of how much animal food we eat and drink can be good for our health and the planet.

fruits and veggies are packed with important stuff like vitamins, minerals, and antioxidants that help our bodies fight diseases. like, people who eat mostly plant foods were 39% less likely to get covid and have fewer hospital visits overall.

Q3:

With small changes like this, everyone can help the environment and slow down climate change now, no need to wait for others! Let‚Äôs start small, yeah? Like, try eating meat just once a day, instead of having it at breakfast, lunch, and dinner. üçΩÔ∏è
Q4: More than 70% of farm animals in the UK are raised on factory farms to keep animal products cheap. On these farms, a chicken has only about the space of a laptop, so there's hardly any room to move. It‚Äôs like living under a staircase, like Harry Potter, for your whole life. By choosing to eat less meat or plant-based meats when we can, we can send a message to these farms to make better living conditions for their animals.

fiber is really important for keeping our stomachs healthy, and it's only found in plants, not in animal foods. when we have enough fiber in our meals, we stay full for longer and have more energy throughout the school day, avoiding that tired feeling after lunch. 

changing our habits, like what we eat, can be tricky at first. an easy way to start could be to try more plant-based lunches at school to feel more energetic and ready for the afternoon.

It‚Äôs good to see how much our generation agrees on this. Even if we‚Äôre not trying to be completely vegan, we can all do something to help. Like, we can try the plant-based food in our school cafeteria or some meat alternatives more often.

Hey! Thanks for following along for the first week. üëç

Q9:
If everyone ate less animal foods, the CO2 from food production would drop by 68%. Just by changing our food choices, we could be halfway to stopping climate change.

Climate change is gonna mostly affect us young people 'cause we'll see its outcomes in our lifetime. Instead of being cynical, let's look for small, effective changes that we can make right now. Choosing more plant-based meals or snacks when possible is one of the easiest things we can do.

You can also find out which foods are especially harmful for the climate (hint: the farm animal that is worst for the climate rhymes with ‚Äòwow‚Äô).
Q10: most pigs and chickens in the UK are kept indoors their whole lives and never see sunlight. animals that can't go outside are more stressed and, scientists say, much less happy. we may not be able to change how animals are treated on these farms directly. but we can choose more vegetables and meat alternatives (like plant-based schnitzel, sausages, and burgers) instead of animal meat. this is the quickest way to help make animals' lives better.
Q11:
Veggies and fruits have some helpful stuff that's good for our brains and helps them work well. Just adding a few more veggies (like three extra servings a week) can boost our mood and make us happier. üòÉ

There's no limit to how many plants we can eat‚Äîit's all good for our brains! To start, you could challenge yourself, your friends, or your parents to have more plant-based meals on some days of the week (with an occasional cheat day here and there). What About you?
Q12: animal farming is responsible for 80% of the amazon rainforest loss, farmers need space for cattle and their food. last year, the amazon lost as many trees as there are in the uk and ireland combined. imagine if there were no trees left! yeah, by eating less meat, like choosing veggie burgers for lunch, we can make a difference without changing much. if you eat with others, you can set an example and inspire your friends and classmates to be more mindful about their food choices too.

Q1:
Hello! I‚Äôm Sasha, nice to meet you! Over the next two weeks, I will explore healthy and sustainable eating with you.

A year ago, I started eating more plant-based foods and learned a lot along the way. It‚Äôs not about being perfect; I don‚Äôt think we all need to go completely vegan. However, being a bit mindful of how much animal food we eat and drink can be good for our health and the planet.

Stay tuned, as I will share lots of interesting science facts and give you tips for small changes that can make a big difference.
Q2: Fruits and vegetables are filled with important nutrients like vitamins, minerals, and antioxidants that help our bodies fight diseases. For instance, people who eat mostly plant foods were 39% less likely to get Covid and have fewer hospital visits overall.\n\nEvery time we buy food ourselves, we get to decide what goes into our bodies. To make it more fun, you could also talk with your friends during lunch and try out some plant-based foods together.
Q3: Reducing how much meat we eat can help save a lot of CO2, which causes climate change. For example, if we eat meat every other day instead of every day for a year, it saves as much CO2 as driving a car from London to China‚Ä¶ and back!\n\nWith small changes like this, everyone can help the environment and slow down climate change now without waiting for others! Let‚Äôs start small;  for example, we can try to eat meat only once a day, instead of having it at breakfast, lunch, and dinner.
Q4: More than 70% of farm animals in the UK are raised on factory farms to keep animal products cheap. On these farms, a chicken has only about the space of a laptop, so there's hardly any room to move. It's like living under a staircase, like Harry Potter, for your whole life.\n\nFactory farms keep going because people buy their products. By choosing to eat less meat or plant-based meats when we can, we can send a message to these farms to make better living conditions for their animals.
Q5: Fiber is really important for keeping our stomachs healthy, and it's only found in plants, not in animal foods. When we have enough fiber in our meals, we stay full for longer and have more energy throughout the school day, avoiding that tired feeling after lunch.\n\nChanging our habits, like what we eat, can be tricky at first. An easy way to start could be to try more plant-based lunches at school to feel more energetic and ready for the afternoon.
Q6: 80% of young people believe that living sustainably is very important for their happiness. And 77% say they would choose meat alternatives as part of their sustainable lifestyle.\n\nIt's good to see how much our generation agrees on this. Even if we're not trying to be completely vegan, each of us can do something to help. For example, we can try the plant-based food options in our school cafeteria or some meat alternatives more often.
Q7: Hey! Thanks for following along for the first week. I'm excited to see how more people are choosing plant-based eating. Some of my favourite celebrities eat vegan, like Lewis Hamilton, Billie Eilish, and Ariana Grande. Others, like Harry Styles and Lionel Messi, avoid animal products for the most part. I also see new plant-based products and restaurants appearing everywhere. It looks like we'll have lots of options in the future! Why not see if some of your favourite celebrities also eat plant-based?
Q8: Cutting down on meat, dairy, and sugary foods can really help with acne ‚Äì up to 87% less for young people. Eating lots of veggies and fruits keeps our skin hydrated, protects from sunburn, and even stops wrinkles. Having clear, glowing skin might be as simple as eating more veggies and fruits. When do you usually buy food during your day? Are there tasty plant-based options you could try next time you have a choice?
Q9:
If we all ate less animal foods, CO2 from food production would drop by 68%. Just by changing our food choices, we'd be halfway to stopping climate change.

Climate change will mostly affect us young people 'cause we'll see its outcomes in our lifetime. Instead of being cynical, let's look for small, effective changes we can make right now. Choosing more plant-based meals or snacks when possible is one of the easiest things we can do.

You can also find out which foods are especially harmful for the climate (hint: the farm animal that's worst for the climate rhymes with ‚Äòwow‚Äô).
Q10: Most pigs and chickens in the UK are kept indoors their whole lives, never see sunlight. Animals that can't go outside are more stressed and, scientists say, much less happy. We may not be able to change how animals are treated on these farms directly. But we can choose more vegetables and meat alternatives (like plant-based schnitzel, sausages, and burgers) instead of animal meat. This is the quickest way to help make animals' lives better.
Q11: Veggies and fruits have stuff that's great for our brains and helps them work well. Just adding a few more veggies, like three extra servings each week, can boost our mood and make us happier. There's no limit to how many plants we can eat‚Äîit's all good for our brains! You could challenge yourself, your friends, or your parents to have more plant-based meals on some days of the week (with an occasional cheat day here and there).
Q12: Animal farming, it's why the Amazon rainforest is gone by 80%. Farmers need space for cattle and their food. Last year, the Amazon lost as many trees as there are in the UK and Ireland together. Imagine if there were no trees left here! By eating less meat, like veggie burgers for lunch, we can make a difference. If you eat with others, you can set an example, inspire your friends and classmates to be more mindful about their food choices too. Yeah, it's that simple.

If everyone ate a bit less animal foods, the CO2 from food production would drop by 68%. Just by changing our food choices, we could be halfway to stopping climate change.

Climate change will mostly affect us young people because we'll see its outcomes in our lifetime. Instead of being cynical, let's look for small, effective changes that we can make right now. Choosing more plant-based meals or snacks when possible is one of the easiest things we can do.

You can also find out which foods are especially harmful for the climate (hint: the farm animal that is worst for the climate rhymes with ‚Äòwow‚Äô).
Q10:
Most pigs and chickens in the UK are kept indoors for their whole lives and never get to see sunlight. Animals that can't go outside are much more stressed and, well, scientists say they're much less happy.

We might not be able to change how animals are treated on these farms directly. But we can choose to have more vegetables and meat alternatives, like plant-based schnitzel, sausages, and burgers, instead of animal meat. That's probably the quickest way to help make animals' lives better, I suppose.
Q11: Vegetables and fruits have these really helpful plant things that are good for our brain health and help it work well. Just adding a few more veggies - like three extra bits a week - can already boost our mood and make us feel happier! There's no limit to how many plants we can eat, it's all good for our brains! You could maybe challenge yourself, your friends, or your parents to have more plant-based meals on some days of the week (with the odd cheat day here and there).
Q12: Animal farming is responsible for, like, 80% of the loss of the Amazon rainforest because farmers need space for cattle and cattle food. Last year, the Amazon lost as many trees as there are in the UK and Ireland combined. Imagine if there were no trees left here at all! By eating less meat (like choosing veggie burgers instead of regular burgers for lunch), we can actually make a difference without needing to change much. If you eat with others, you can also set an example and inspire your friends and classmates to be more mindful about their food choices as well.

Q1:
Hello! I‚Äôm Sasha, nice to meet you! Over the next two weeks, I will explore healthy and sustainable eating with you.

A year ago, I started eating more plant-based foods and learned a lot along the way. It‚Äôs not about being perfect; I don‚Äôt think we all need to go completely vegan. However, being a bit mindful of how much animal food we eat and drink can be good for our health and the planet.

Stay tuned, as I will share lots of interesting science facts and give you tips for small changes that can make a big difference.
Q2: Fruits and vegetables are filled with important nutrients like vitamins, minerals, and antioxidants that help our bodies fight diseases. For instance, people who eat mostly plant foods were 39% less likely to get Covid and have fewer hospital visits overall.\n\nEvery time we buy food ourselves, we get to decide what goes into our bodies. To make it more fun, you could also talk with your friends during lunch and try out some plant-based foods together.
Q3: Reducing how much meat we eat can help save a lot of CO2, which causes climate change. For example, if we eat meat every other day instead of every day for a year, it saves as much CO2 as driving a car from London to China‚Ä¶ and back!\n\nWith small changes like this, everyone can help the environment and slow down climate change now without waiting for others! Let‚Äôs start small;  for example, we can try to eat meat only once a day, instead of having it at breakfast, lunch, and dinner.
Q4: More than 70% of farm animals in the UK are raised on factory farms to keep animal products cheap. On these farms, a chicken has only about the space of a laptop, so there's hardly any room to move. It's like living under a staircase, like Harry Potter, for your whole life.\n\nFactory farms keep going because people buy their products. By choosing to eat less meat or plant-based meats when we can, we can send a message to these farms to make better living conditions for their animals.
Q5: Fiber is really important for keeping our stomachs healthy, and it's only found in plants, not in animal foods. When we have enough fiber in our meals, we stay full for longer and have more energy throughout the school day, avoiding that tired feeling after lunch.\n\nChanging our habits, like what we eat, can be tricky at first. An easy way to start could be to try more plant-based lunches at school to feel more energetic and ready for the afternoon.
Q6: 80% of young people believe that living sustainably is very important for their happiness. And 77% say they would choose meat alternatives as part of their sustainable lifestyle.\n\nIt's good to see how much our generation agrees on this. Even if we're not trying to be completely vegan, each of us can do something to help. For example, we can try the plant-based food options in our school cafeteria or some meat alternatives more often.

Q1:
Hello! I‚Äôm Sasha, nice to meet you! Over the next two weeks, I will explore healthy and sustainable eating with you.

A year ago, I started eating more plant-based foods and learned a lot along the way. It‚Äôs not about being perfect; I don‚Äôt think we all need to go completely vegan. However, being a bit mindful of how much animal food we eat and drink can be good for our health and the planet.

Stay tuned, as I will share lots of interesting science facts and give you tips for small changes that can make a big difference.
Q2: Fruits and vegetables are filled with important nutrients like vitamins, minerals, and antioxidants that help our bodies fight diseases. For instance, people who eat mostly plant foods were 39% less likely to get Covid and have fewer hospital visits overall.\n\nEvery time we buy food ourselves, we get to decide what goes into our bodies. To make it more fun, you could also talk with your friends during lunch and try out some plant-based foods together.
Q3: Reducing how much meat we eat can help save a lot of CO2, which causes climate change. For example, if we eat meat every other day instead of every day for a year, it saves as much CO2 as driving a car from London to China‚Ä¶ and back!\n\nWith small changes like this, everyone can help the environment and slow down climate change now without waiting for others! Let‚Äôs start small;  for example, we can try to eat meat only once a day, instead of having it at breakfast, lunch, and dinner.
Q4: More than 70% of farm animals in the UK are raised on factory farms to keep animal products cheap. On these farms, a chicken has only about the space of a laptop, so there's hardly any room to move. It's like living under a staircase, like Harry Potter, for your whole life.\n\nFactory farms keep going because people buy their products. By choosing to eat less meat or plant-based meats when we can, we can send a message to these farms to make better living conditions for their animals.
Q5: Fiber is really important for keeping our stomachs healthy, and it's only found in plants, not in animal foods. When we have enough fiber in our meals, we stay full for longer and have more energy throughout the school day, avoiding that tired feeling after lunch.\n\nChanging our habits, like what we eat, can be tricky at first. An easy way to start could be to try more plant-based lunches at school to feel more energetic and ready for the afternoon.
Q6: 80% of young people believe that living sustainably is very important for their happiness. And 77% say they would choose meat alternatives as part of their sustainable lifestyle.\n\nIt's good to see how much our generation agrees on this. Even if we're not trying to be completely vegan, each of us can do something to help. For example, we can try the plant-based food options in our school cafeteria or some meat alternatives more often.
Q7:
Hey! Thanks for following along for the first week.

Very exciting to see more people choosing plant-based eating. Some of my favorite celebrities eat vegan, like Lewis Hamilton, Billie Eilish, and Ariana Grande. Others, like Harry Styles and Lionel Messi, avoid animal products for the most part.

I also see new plant-based products and restaurants appearing everywhere. It looks like we'll have lots of options in the future!

Why not see if some of your favorite celebrities also eat plant-based?
Q8:
Reducing meat, dairy, and sugary foods can really help improve acne. Up to 87% less acne in young people. Eating lots of vegetables and fruits keeps our skin hydrated, protects from sunburn, and even stops wrinkles.

Having clear, glowing skin might be as simple as just eating more veggies and fruits. When do you usually buy food during your day? Are there tasty plant-based options you could try next time you have a choice?
Q9:
If we all eat less animal foods, the CO2 from food production will drop by 68%. Just by changing our food choices, we could be halfway to stopping climate change.

Climate change will mostly affect us young people because we will see its outcomes in our lifetime. Instead of being cynical, let's look for small, effective changes that we can make right now. Choosing more plant-based meals or snacks when possible is one of the easiest things we can do.

Do you know which foods are especially harmful for the climate? Hint: the farm animal that is worst for the climate rhymes with ‚Äòwow‚Äô.
Q10: Most pigs and chickens in the UK are kept indoors their whole lives. Never see sunlight. Animals that can't go outside are more stressed. Scientists say they are much less happy. We may not be able to change how animals are treated on these farms directly. But we can choose more vegetables and meat alternatives. Like plant-based schnitzel, sausages, and burgers. This is the quickest way to help make animals' lives better.
Q11: Vegetables and fruits have helpful plant substances that support our brain health and help it work well. Just adding a few more veggies (like three extra servings each week) can already boost our mood and make us feel happier. There's no limit to how many plants we can eat‚Äîit's all good for our brains! To start, you could challenge yourself, your friends, or your parents to have more plant-based meals on some days of the week (with an occasional cheat day here and there).
Q12: Animal farming is responsible for 80% of the Amazon rainforest loss. Farmers need space for cattle and cattle food. Last year, the Amazon lost as many trees as there are in the UK and Ireland combined. Imagine if not a single tree was left! By eating less meat, like choosing veggie burgers for lunch, we can make a difference. If you eat with others, you can set an example and inspire your friends and classmates to be more mindful about their food choices.

Q1:
Hello! I‚Äôm Sasha, nice to meet you! Over the next two weeks, I will explore healthy and sustainable eating with you.

A year ago, I started eating more plant-based foods and learned a lot along the way. It‚Äôs not about being perfect; I don‚Äôt think we all need to go completely vegan. However, being a bit mindful of how much animal food we eat and drink can be good for our health and the planet.

Stay tuned, as I will share lots of interesting science facts and give you tips for small changes that can make a big difference.
Q2: Fruits and vegetables are filled with important nutrients like vitamins, minerals, and antioxidants that help our bodies fight diseases. For instance, people who eat mostly plant foods were 39% less likely to get Covid and have fewer hospital visits overall.\n\nEvery time we buy food ourselves, we get to decide what goes into our bodies. To make it more fun, you could also talk with your friends during lunch and try out some plant-based foods together.
Q3: Reducing how much meat we eat can help save a lot of CO2, which causes climate change. For example, if we eat meat every other day instead of every day for a year, it saves as much CO2 as driving a car from London to China‚Ä¶ and back!\n\nWith small changes like this, everyone can help the environment and slow down climate change now without waiting for others! Let‚Äôs start small;  for example, we can try to eat meat only once a day, instead of having it at breakfast, lunch, and dinner.
Q4: More than 70% of farm animals in the UK are raised on factory farms to keep animal products cheap. On these farms, a chicken has only about the space of a laptop, so there's hardly any room to move. It's like living under a staircase, like Harry Potter, for your whole life.\n\nFactory farms keep going because people buy their products. By choosing to eat less meat or plant-based meats when we can, we can send a message to these farms to make better living conditions for their animals.
Q5: Fiber is really important for keeping our stomachs healthy, and it's only found in plants, not in animal foods. When we have enough fiber in our meals, we stay full for longer and have more energy throughout the school day, avoiding that tired feeling after lunch.\n\nChanging our habits, like what we eat, can be tricky at first. An easy way to start could be to try more plant-based lunches at school to feel more energetic and ready for the afternoon.
Q6: 80% of young people believe that living sustainably is very important for their happiness. And 77% say they would choose meat alternatives as part of their sustainable lifestyle.\n\nIt's good to see how much our generation agrees on this. Even if we're not trying to be completely vegan, each of us can do something to help. For example, we can try the plant-based food options in our school cafeteria or some meat alternatives more often.
Q7:
Hey! Thanks for following along for the first week.

I'm excited to see how more people are choosing plant-based eating. Some of my favourite celebrities eat vegan, like Lewis Hamilton, Billie Eilish, and Ariana Grande. Others, like Harry Styles and Lionel Messi, avoid animal products for the most part.

I also see new plant-based products and restaurants appearing everywhere.  It looks like we'll have lots of options in the future!

Why not see if some of your favorite celebrities also eat plant-based?
Q8: Reducing how much meat, dairy, and sugary foods we eat can really help improve acne (up to 87% less acne in young people). Eating lots of vegetables and fruits also keeps our skin hydrated, protects us from getting sunburned, and even stops wrinkles.\n\nHaving clear, glowing skin might be as simple as just eating more veggies and fruits. When do you usually buy food during your day? Are there tasty plant-based options you could try the next time you have a choice?
Q9:
If everyone ate less animal foods, the CO2 from food production would drop by 68%. Just by changing our food choices, we could be halfway to stopping climate change.

Climate change will mostly affect us young people because we will see its outcomes in our lifetime. Instead of being cynical, let's look for small, effective changes that we can make right now. Choosing more plant-based meals or snacks when possible is one of the easiest things we can do.

You can also find out which foods are especially harmful for to climate (hint: the farm animal that is worst for the climate rhymes with ‚Äòwow‚Äô).
Q10: Most pigs and chickens in the UK are kept indoors their whole lives and never see sunlight. Animals that can't go outside are more stressed and, scientists say, much less happy.\n\nWe may not be able to change how animals are treated on these farms directly. But we can choose more vegetables and meat alternatives (like plant-based schnitzel, sausages, and burgers) instead of animal meat. This is the quickest way to help make animals' lives better.
Q11: Vegetables and fruits have helpful plant substances that support our brain health and help it work well. Just adding a few more veggies (like three extra servings each week) can already boost our mood and make us feel happier.\n\nThere's no limit to how many plants we can eat‚Äîit's all good for our brains! To start, you could challenge yourself, your friends, or your parents to have more plant-based meals on some days of the week (with an occasional cheat day here and there).
Q12: Animal farming is responsible for 80% of the loss of the Amazon rainforest because farmers need space for cattle and cattle food. Last year, the Amazon rainforest lost as many trees as there are in the UK and Ireland combined. Imagine if there were not a single tree left here!\n\nBy eating less meat (like choosing veggie burgers instead of regular burgers for lunch), we can make a difference without needing to change much. If you eat with others, you can also set an example and inspire your friends and classmates, to be more mindful about their food choices as well.

Q1:
Hello my friend! I‚Äôm Sasha, nice to meet you! So, over the next two weeks, I will explore healthy and sustainable eating with you.

You see, a year ago, I started eating more plant-based foods and learned a lot along the way. It‚Äôs not about being perfect; I don‚Äôt think we all need to go completely vegan. But, being a bit mindful of how much animal food we eat and drink can be good for our health and the planet.

So, stay tuned, as I will share lots of interesting science facts and give you tips for small changes that can make a big difference.
Q2: Hello my friend, fruits and vegetables are packed with important nutrients like vitamins, minerals, and antioxidants that help our bodies fight diseases. For instance, people who eat mostly plant foods were 39% less likely to get Covid and have fewer hospital visits overall. Every time we buy food ourselves, we get to decide what goes into our bodies. To make it more fun, you could also talk with your friends during lunch and try out some plant-based foods together. Yes, it's a great idea!
Q3:
Hello my friend, reducing how much meat we eat can really help save a lot of CO2, you know, the stuff that causes climate change. For example, if we eat meat every other day instead of every day for a year, it saves as much CO2 as driving a car from London to China and back! Isn't that something?

With small changes like this, everyone can help the environment and slow down climate change now without waiting for others! Let‚Äôs start small, okay? For example, we can try to eat meat only once a day, instead of having it at breakfast, lunch, and dinner. Yes, we can do it!
Q4: Hello my friend, did you know more than 70% of farm animals in the UK are raised on factory farms? It's just to keep animal products cheap. In these places, a chicken has only about the space of a laptop. Can you imagine? Hardly any room to move. It's like living under a staircase, like Harry Potter, for your whole life. These farms keep going because we buy their products. But I think we can make a change. We can choose to eat less meat or try plant-based meats. That way, we send a message to these farms to make better living conditions for their animals. Yes, we can.
Q5: Hello my friend, fiber is really important to keep our stomachs healthy. It's only found in plants, not in animal foods. When we have enough fiber in our meals, we stay full for longer and have more energy throughout the school day. We can avoid that tired feeling after lunch. Yes, changing our habits, like what we eat, can be tricky at first. But I think an easy way to start could be to try more plant-based lunches at school. This way, you can feel more energetic and ready for the afternoon.
Q6: Hello my friend, did you know that 80% of young people think living sustainably is super important for their happiness? And guess what, 77% say they'd go for meat alternatives for a sustainable lifestyle. It's amazing to see our generation on the same page. Even if we're not going full vegan, we all can do our part. Like, we can try those plant-based options in our school cafeteria or some meat alternatives more often. Yes, we can!
Q7: Hello my friend, thanks for following along for the first week. I am excited to see how more people are choosing plant-based eating. Yes, some of my favourite celebrities eat vegan, like Lewis Hamilton, Billie Eilish, and Ariana Grande. Others, like Harry Styles and Lionel Messi, avoid animal products for the most part. I also see new plant-based products and restaurants appearing everywhere. It looks like we'll have lots of options in the future! Why not see if some of your favorite celebrities also eat plant-based?
Q8: Hello my friend, reducing how much meat, dairy, and sugary foods we eat can really help improve acne. Yes, it can reduce acne in young people by up to 87%. Eating lots of vegetables and fruits also keeps our skin hydrated, protects us from getting sunburned, and even stops wrinkles. I think having clear, glowing skin might be as simple as just eating more veggies and fruits. Tell me, when do you usually buy food during your day? Are there tasty plant-based options you could try the next time you have a choice?
Q9:
Hello my friend, if everyone ate less animal foods, the CO2 from food production would drop by 68%. Just by changing our food choices, we could be halfway to stopping climate change.

Climate change will mostly affect us young people because we will see its outcomes in our lifetime. But don't be cynical, let's look for small, effective changes that we can make right now. Choosing more plant-based meals or snacks when possible is one of the easiest things we can do.

You can also find out which foods are especially harmful for the climate. I'll give you a hint: the farm animal that is worst for the climate rhymes with ‚Äòwow‚Äô. Yes, you got it!
Q10: Hello my friend, did you know most pigs and chickens in the UK are kept indoors their whole lives? They never see sunlight. Animals that can't go outside are more stressed and, scientists say, much less happy. We may not be able to change how animals are treated on these farms directly. But I think we can choose more vegetables and meat alternatives, like plant-based schnitzel, sausages, and burgers, instead of animal meat. This is the quickest way to help make animals' lives better. Yes?
Q11: Hello my friend, vegetables and fruits have helpful plant substances that support our brain health and help it work well. Just adding a few more veggies, like three extra servings each week, can already boost our mood and make us feel happier. There's no limit to how many plants we can eat‚Äîit's all good for our brains! You should challenge yourself, your friends, or your parents to have more plant-based meals on some days of the week. Yes, you can have an occasional cheat day here and there.
Q12: Hello my friend, animal farming is responsible for 80% of the Amazon rainforest loss. You know why? Because farmers need space for cattle and their food. Last year, the Amazon lost as many trees as there are in the UK and Ireland combined. Imagine if there were no trees left here! It's shocking, right? But you know what? By eating less meat, like choosing veggie burgers for lunch, we can make a difference. It's not that hard. And if you eat with others, you can set an example and inspire your friends and classmates to be more mindful about their food choices. Yes, you can do it!

Q1: Hi! I'm Sasha, nice to meet you! Over the next two weeks, I'll explore healthy and sustainable eating with you. A year ago, I started eating more plant-based foods and learned lots along the way. It's not about being perfect; I don't think we all need to go completely vegan. But being a bit mindful of how much animal food we eat and drink can be good for our health and the planet. Stay tuned, as I'll share lots of interesting science facts and give you tips for small changes that can make a big difference.
Q2: Fruits and veg have lots of important stuff like vitamins and minerals that help us fight diseases. Like people who eat mostly plant foods were 39% less likely to get Covid and have fewer hospital visits. Every time we buy food we decide what goes in our bodies. To make it fun you could talk with your friends at lunch and try some plant-based foods together.
Q3: Like if we eat meat every other day instead of every day for a year it saves loads of CO2 like driving a car from London to China and back! So we can start small and try to eat meat once a day instead of breakfast lunch and dinner. Little bits help lots!
Q4: More than 70% of farm animals in the UK are raised on factory farms to keep animal products cheap. On these farms, a chicken has only about the space of a laptop, so there's hardly any room to move. It's like living under a staircase, like Harry Potter, for your whole life. Factory farms keep going because people buy their products. By choosing to eat less meat or plant-based meats when we can, we can send a message to these farms to make better living conditions for their animals.
Q5:
Fiber is important for our stomachs, it's in plants, not animal foods. When we have enough fiber, we stay full longer and have more energy for school, no tired feeling after lunch.

Changing what we eat can be tricky. Easy way to start is try plant-based lunches at school, feel more energetic for the afternoon.
Q6: 80% of young people think living sustainably is really important for being happy. And 77% say they'd pick meat alternatives for a sustainable lifestyle. It's cool how much our generation agrees on this. Even if we're not trying to be completely vegan, we can all do something to help. Like we can try plant-based food in our school cafeteria or some meat alternatives more often.
Q7: Hi! Thanks for following along for the first week. I'm excited seeing more people choosing plant-based eating. Some of my favourite celebrities eat vegan, like Lewis Hamilton, Billie Eilish, and Ariana Grande. Others like Harry Styles and Lionel Messi avoid animal products for the most part. I see new plant-based products and restaurants appearing everywhere. Looks like we'll have lots of options in the future! Why not see if some of your favourite celebrities also eat plant-based?
Q8:
Eating less meat, dairy, and sugary stuff can really help with acne like up to 87% less for young people. Eating lots of veggies and fruits keeps skin hydrated, stops sunburn, and even stops wrinkles.

Having clear, glowing skin might be as simple as eating more veggies and fruits. When do you usually buy food? Are there tasty plant-based stuff you could try next time?
Q9:
If everyone ate less animal foods, the CO2 from food would drop by 68%. Just by changing what we eat, we could be halfway to stopping climate change.

Climate change will mostly affect us young people because we'll see it in our lifetime. Instead of being cynical, let's look for small, easy changes we can make now. Choosing more plant-based meals or snacks is one of the easiest things we can do.

You can also find out which foods are bad for the climate (hint: the farm animal that's worst for the climate rhymes with ‚Äòwow‚Äô).
Q10: Most pigs and chickens in the UK are kept indoors all their lives and never see sunlight. Animals that can't go outside are more stressed and scientists say much less happy. We may not be able to change how animals are treated on these farms directly. But we can choose more vegetables and meat alternatives like plant-based schnitzel, sausages, and burgers instead of animal meat. This is the quickest way to help make animals' lives better.
Q11: Veggies and fruits have good stuff that helps our brain work well. Just adding some more veggies like three extra bits each week can make us feel happier. No limit to how many plants we can eat its all good for our brains! You could challenge yourself or your friends or parents to have more plant meals on some days with cheat days here and there.
Q12: Animal farming is why 80% of the Amazon rainforest is gone, farmers need space for cattle and their food. Last year, the Amazon lost as many trees as there are in the UK and Ireland together. Imagine if there were no trees left here! By eating less meat, like choosing veggie burgers for lunch, we can make a difference without changing much. If you eat with others, you can set an example and inspire your friends and classmates to be more mindful about their food choices too.

But if we eat less meat, like choosing veggie burgers for lunch, we can make a difference without much change. When you eat with others, you can set an example and inspire your friends and classmates to be more mindful about their food choices too.

Q1:
Hello! I‚Äôm Sasha, nice to meet you! Over the next two weeks, I will explore healthy and sustainable eating with you.

A year ago, I started eating more plant-based foods and learned a lot along the way. It‚Äôs not about being perfect; I don‚Äôt think we all need to go completely vegan. However, being a bit mindful of how much animal food we eat and drink can be good for our health and the planet.

Stay tuned, as I will share lots of interesting science facts and give you tips for small changes that can make a big difference.
Q2: Fruits and vegetables are filled with important nutrients like vitamins, minerals, and antioxidants that help our bodies fight diseases. For instance, people who eat mostly plant foods were 39% less likely to get Covid and have fewer hospital visits overall.\n\nEvery time we buy food ourselves, we get to decide what goes into our bodies. To make it more fun, you could also talk with your friends during lunch and try out some plant-based foods together.
Q3: Reducing how much meat we eat can help save a lot of CO2, which causes climate change. For example, if we eat meat every other day instead of every day for a year, it saves as much CO2 as driving a car from London to China‚Ä¶ and back!\n\nWith small changes like this, everyone can help the environment and slow down climate change now without waiting for others! Let‚Äôs start small;  for example, we can try to eat meat only once a day, instead of having it at breakfast, lunch, and dinner.
Q4: More than 70% of farm animals in the UK are raised on factory farms to keep animal products cheap. On these farms, a chicken has only about the space of a laptop, so there's hardly any room to move. It's like living under a staircase, like Harry Potter, for your whole life.\n\nFactory farms keep going because people buy their products. By choosing to eat less meat or plant-based meats when we can, we can send a message to these farms to make better living conditions for their animals.
Q5: Fiber is really important for keeping our stomachs healthy, and it's only found in plants, not in animal foods. When we have enough fiber in our meals, we stay full for longer and have more energy throughout the school day, avoiding that tired feeling after lunch.\n\nChanging our habits, like what we eat, can be tricky at first. An easy way to start could be to try more plant-based lunches at school to feel more energetic and ready for the afternoon.
Q6: 80% of young people believe that living sustainably is very important for their happiness. And 77% say they would choose meat alternatives as part of their sustainable lifestyle.\n\nIt's good to see how much our generation agrees on this. Even if we're not trying to be completely vegan, each of us can do something to help. For example, we can try the plant-based food options in our school cafeteria or some meat alternatives more often.
Q7:
Hey! Thanks for following along for the first week.

I'm excited to see how more people are choosing plant-based eating. Some of my favourite celebrities eat vegan, like Lewis Hamilton, Billie Eilish, and Ariana Grande. Others, like Harry Styles and Lionel Messi, avoid animal products for the most part.

I also see new plant-based products and restaurants appearing everywhere.  It looks like we'll have lots of options in the future!

Why not see if some of your favorite celebrities also eat plant-based?
Q8: Reducing how much meat, dairy, and sugary foods we eat can really help improve acne (up to 87% less acne in young people). Eating lots of vegetables and fruits also keeps our skin hydrated, protects us from getting sunburned, and even stops wrinkles.\n\nHaving clear, glowing skin might be as simple as just eating more veggies and fruits. When do you usually buy food during your day? Are there tasty plant-based options you could try the next time you have a choice?
Q9:
If everyone ate less animal foods, the CO2 from food production would drop by 68%. Just by changing our food choices, we could be halfway to stopping climate change.

Climate change will mostly affect us young people because we will see its outcomes in our lifetime. Instead of being cynical, let's look for small, effective changes that we can make right now. Choosing more plant-based meals or snacks when possible is one of the easiest things we can do.

You can also find out which foods are especially harmful for to climate (hint: the farm animal that is worst for the climate rhymes with ‚Äòwow‚Äô).
Q10: Most pigs and chickens in the UK are kept indoors their whole lives and never see sunlight. Animals that can't go outside are more stressed and, scientists say, much less happy.\n\nWe may not be able to change how animals are treated on these farms directly. But we can choose more vegetables and meat alternatives (like plant-based schnitzel, sausages, and burgers) instead of animal meat. This is the quickest way to help make animals' lives better.
Q11: Vegetables and fruits have helpful plant substances that support our brain health and help it work well. Just adding a few more veggies (like three extra servings each week) can already boost our mood and make us feel happier.\n\nThere's no limit to how many plants we can eat‚Äîit's all good for our brains! To start, you could challenge yourself, your friends, or your parents to have more plant-based meals on some days of the week (with an occasional cheat day here and there).
Q12: Animal farming is responsible for 80% of the loss of the Amazon rainforest because farmers need space for cattle and cattle food. Last year, the Amazon rainforest lost as many trees as there are in the UK and Ireland combined. Imagine if there were not a single tree left here!\n\nBy eating less meat (like choosing veggie burgers instead of regular burgers for lunch), we can make a difference without needing to change much. If you eat with others, you can also set an example and inspire your friends and classmates, to be more mindful about their food choices as well.

Q1:
Hello! I‚Äôm Sasha, nice to meet you! Over the next two weeks, I will explore healthy and sustainable eating with you.

A year ago, I started eating more plant-based foods and learned a lot along the way. It‚Äôs not about being perfect; I don‚Äôt think we all need to go completely vegan. However, being a bit mindful of how much animal food we eat and drink can be good for our health and the planet.

Stay tuned, as I will share lots of interesting science facts and give you tips for small changes that can make a big difference.
Q2: Fruits and vegetables are filled with important nutrients like vitamins, minerals, and antioxidants that help our bodies fight diseases. For instance, people who eat mostly plant foods were 39% less likely to get Covid and have fewer hospital visits overall.\n\nEvery time we buy food ourselves, we get to decide what goes into our bodies. To make it more fun, you could also talk with your friends during lunch and try out some plant-based foods together.
Q3: Reducing how much meat we eat can help save a lot of CO2, which causes climate change. For example, if we eat meat every other day instead of every day for a year, it saves as much CO2 as driving a car from London to China‚Ä¶ and back!\n\nWith small changes like this, everyone can help the environment and slow down climate change now without waiting for others! Let‚Äôs start small;  for example, we can try to eat meat only once a day, instead of having it at breakfast, lunch, and dinner.
Q4: More than 70% of farm animals in the UK are raised on factory farms to keep animal products cheap. On these farms, a chicken has only about the space of a laptop, so there's hardly any room to move. It's like living under a staircase, like Harry Potter, for your whole life.\n\nFactory farms keep going because people buy their products. By choosing to eat less meat or plant-based meats when we can, we can send a message to these farms to make better living conditions for their animals.
Q5: Fiber is really important for keeping our stomachs healthy, and it's only found in plants, not in animal foods. When we have enough fiber in our meals, we stay full for longer and have more energy throughout the school day, avoiding that tired feeling after lunch.\n\nChanging our habits, like what we eat, can be tricky at first. An easy way to start could be to try more plant-based lunches at school to feel more energetic and ready for the afternoon.
Q6: 80% of young people believe that living sustainably is very important for their happiness. And 77% say they would choose meat alternatives as part of their sustainable lifestyle.\n\nIt's good to see how much our generation agrees on this. Even if we're not trying to be completely vegan, each of us can do something to help. For example, we can try the plant-based food options in our school cafeteria or some meat alternatives more often.
Q7:
Hey! Thanks for following along for the first week.

I'm excited to see how more people are choosing plant-based eating. Some of my favourite celebrities eat vegan, like Lewis Hamilton, Billie Eilish, and Ariana Grande. Others, like Harry Styles and Lionel Messi, avoid animal products for the most part.

I also see new plant-based products and restaurants appearing everywhere.  It looks like we'll have lots of options in the future!

Why not see if some of your favorite celebrities also eat plant-based?
Q8: Reducing how much meat, dairy, and sugary foods we eat can really help improve acne (up to 87% less acne in young people). Eating lots of vegetables and fruits also keeps our skin hydrated, protects us from getting sunburned, and even stops wrinkles.\n\nHaving clear, glowing skin might be as simple as just eating more veggies and fruits. When do you usually buy food during your day? Are there tasty plant-based options you could try the next time you have a choice?
Q9:
If everyone ate less animal foods, the CO2 from food production would drop by 68%. Just by changing our food choices, we could be halfway to stopping climate change.

Climate change will mostly affect us young people because we will see its outcomes in our lifetime. Instead of being cynical, let's look for small, effective changes that we can make right now. Choosing more plant-based meals or snacks when possible is one of the easiest things we can do.

You can also find out which foods are especially harmful for to climate (hint: the farm animal that is worst for the climate rhymes with ‚Äòwow‚Äô).
Q10: Most pigs and chickens in the UK are kept indoors their whole lives and never see sunlight. Animals that can't go outside are more stressed and, scientists say, much less happy.\n\nWe may not be able to change how animals are treated on these farms directly. But we can choose more vegetables and meat alternatives (like plant-based schnitzel, sausages, and burgers) instead of animal meat. This is the quickest way to help make animals' lives better.
Q11: Vegetables and fruits have helpful plant substances that support our brain health and help it work well. Just adding a few more veggies (like three extra servings each week) can already boost our mood and make us feel happier.\n\nThere's no limit to how many plants we can eat‚Äîit's all good for our brains! To start, you could challenge yourself, your friends, or your parents to have more plant-based meals on some days of the week (with an occasional cheat day here and there).
Q12: Animal farming is responsible for 80% of the loss of the Amazon rainforest because farmers need space for cattle and cattle food. Last year, the Amazon rainforest lost as many trees as there are in the UK and Ireland combined. Imagine if there were not a single tree left here!\n\nBy eating less meat (like choosing veggie burgers instead of regular burgers for lunch), we can make a difference without needing to change much. If you eat with others, you can also set an example and inspire your friends and classmates, to be more mindful about their food choices as well.

Q4: More than 70% of farm animals in the UK are raised on factory farms to keep animal products cheap. On these farms, a chicken has only about the space of a laptop, so there's hardly any room to move. It's like living under a staircase, like Harry Potter, for your whole life.\n\nFactory farms keep going because people buy their products. By choosing to eat less meat or plant-based meats when we can, we can send a message to these farms to make better living conditions for their animals.
Q5: Fiber is really important for keeping our stomachs healthy, and it's only found in plants, not in animal foods. When we have enough fiber in our meals, we stay full for longer and have more energy throughout the school day, avoiding that tired feeling after lunch.\n\nChanging our habits, like what we eat, can be tricky at first. An easy way to start could be to try more plant-based lunches at school to feel more energetic and ready for the afternoon.
Q6: 80% of young people believe that living sustainably is very important for their happiness. And 77% say they would choose meat alternatives as part of their sustainable lifestyle.\n\nIt's good to see how much our generation agrees on this. Even if we're not trying to be completely vegan, each of us can do something to help. For example, we can try the plant-based food options in our school cafeteria or some meat alternatives more often.
Q7:
Hey! Thanks for following along for the first week.

I'm excited to see how more people are choosing plant-based eating. Some of my favourite celebrities eat vegan, like Lewis Hamilton, Billie Eilish, and Ariana Grande. Others, like Harry Styles and Lionel Messi, avoid animal products for the most part.

I also see new plant-based products and restaurants appearing everywhere.  It looks like we'll have lots of options in the future!

Why not see if some of your favorite celebrities also eat plant-based?
Q8: Reducing how much meat, dairy, and sugary foods we eat can really help improve acne (up to 87% less acne in young people). Eating lots of vegetables and fruits also keeps our skin hydrated, protects us from getting sunburned, and even stops wrinkles.\n\nHaving clear, glowing skin might be as simple as just eating more veggies and fruits. When do you usually buy food during your day? Are there tasty plant-based options you could try the next time you have a choice?
Q9:
If everyone ate less animal foods, the CO2 from food production would drop by 68%. Just by changing our food choices, we could be halfway to stopping climate change.

Climate change will mostly affect us young people because we will see its outcomes in our lifetime. Instead of being cynical, let's look for small, effective changes that we can make right now. Choosing more plant-based meals or snacks when possible is one of the easiest things we can do.

You can also find out which foods are especially harmful for to climate (hint: the farm animal that is worst for the climate rhymes with ‚Äòwow‚Äô).
Q10: Most pigs and chickens in the UK are kept indoors their whole lives and never see sunlight. Animals that can't go outside are more stressed and, scientists say, much less happy.\n\nWe may not be able to change how animals are treated on these farms directly. But we can choose more vegetables and meat alternatives (like plant-based schnitzel, sausages, and burgers) instead of animal meat. This is the quickest way to help make animals' lives better.
Q11: Vegetables and fruits have helpful plant substances that support our brain health and help it work well. Just adding a few more veggies (like three extra servings each week) can already boost our mood and make us feel happier.\n\nThere's no limit to how many plants we can eat‚Äîit's all good for our brains! To start, you could challenge yourself, your friends, or your parents to have more plant-based meals on some days of the week (with an occasional cheat day here and there).
Q12: Animal farming is responsible for 80% of the loss of the Amazon rainforest because farmers need space for cattle and cattle food. Last year, the Amazon rainforest lost as many trees as there are in the UK and Ireland combined. Imagine if there were not a single tree left here!\n\nBy eating less meat (like choosing veggie burgers instead of regular burgers for lunch), we can make a difference without needing to change much. If you eat with others, you can also set an example and inspire your friends and classmates, to be more mindful about their food choices as well.

Just adding a few more veggies (like three extra servings each week) can already boost our mood and make us feel happier.\n\nThere's no limit to how many plants we can eat‚Äîit's all good for our brains! To start, you could challenge yourself, your friends, or your parents to have more plant-based meals on some days of the week (with an occasional cheat day here and there).
Q12: Animal farming is responsible for 80% of the loss of the Amazon rainforest because farmers need space for cattle and cattle food. Last year, the Amazon rainforest lost as many trees as there are in the UK and Ireland combined. Imagine if there were not a single tree left here!\n\nBy eating less meat (like choosing veggie burgers instead of regular burgers for lunch), we can make a difference without needing to change much. If you eat with others, you can also set an example and inspire your friends and classmates, to be more mindful about their food choices as well.

Q1:
Hello! I‚Äôm Sasha, nice to meet you! Over the next two weeks, I will explore healthy and sustainable eating with you.

A year ago, I started eating more plant-based foods and learned a lot along the way. It‚Äôs not about being perfect; I don‚Äôt think we all need to go completely vegan. However, being a bit mindful of how much animal food we eat and drink can be good for our health and the planet.

Stay tuned, as I will share lots of interesting science facts and give you tips for small changes that can make a big difference.
Q2: Fruits and vegetables are filled with important nutrients like vitamins, minerals, and antioxidants that help our bodies fight diseases. For instance, people who eat mostly plant foods were 39% less likely to get Covid and have fewer hospital visits overall.\n\nEvery time we buy food ourselves, we get to decide what goes into our bodies. To make it more fun, you could also talk with your friends during lunch and try out some plant-based foods together.
Q3: Reducing how much meat we eat can help save a lot of CO2, which causes climate change. For example, if we eat meat every other day instead of every day for a year, it saves as much CO2 as driving a car from London to China‚Ä¶ and back!\n\nWith small changes like this, everyone can help the environment and slow down climate change now without waiting for others! Let‚Äôs start small;  for example, we can try to eat meat only once a day, instead of having it at breakfast, lunch, and dinner.
Q4: More than 70% of farm animals in the UK are raised on factory farms to keep animal products cheap. On these farms, a chicken has only about the space of a laptop, so there's hardly any room to move. It's like living under a staircase, like Harry Potter, for your whole life.\n\nFactory farms keep going because people buy their products. By choosing to eat less meat or plant-based meats when we can, we can send a message to these farms to make better living conditions for their animals.
Q5: Fiber is really important for keeping our stomachs healthy, and it's only found in plants, not in animal foods. When we have enough fiber in our meals, we stay full for longer and have more energy throughout the school day, avoiding that tired feeling after lunch.\n\nChanging our habits, like what we eat, can be tricky at first. An easy way to start could be to try more plant-based lunches at school to feel more energetic and ready for the afternoon.
Q6: 80% of young people believe that living sustainably is very important for their happiness. And 77% say they would choose meat alternatives as part of their sustainable lifestyle.\n\nIt's good to see how much our generation agrees on this. Even if we're not trying to be completely vegan, each of us can do something to help. For example, we can try the plant-based food options in our school cafeteria or some meat alternatives more often.
Q7:
Hey! Thanks for following along for the first week.

I'm excited to see how more people are choosing plant-based eating. Some of my favourite celebrities eat vegan, like Lewis Hamilton, Billie Eilish, and Ariana Grande. Others, like Harry Styles and Lionel Messi, avoid animal products for the most part.

I also see new plant-based products and restaurants appearing everywhere.  It looks like we'll have lots of options in the future!

Why not see if some of your favorite celebrities also eat plant-based?
Q8: Reducing how much meat, dairy, and sugary foods we eat can really help improve acne (up to 87% less acne in young people). Eating lots of vegetables and fruits also keeps our skin hydrated, protects us from getting sunburned, and even stops wrinkles.\n\nHaving clear, glowing skin might be as simple as just eating more veggies and fruits. When do you usually buy food during your day? Are there tasty plant-based options you could try the next time you have a choice?
Q9:
If everyone ate less animal foods, the CO2 from food production would drop by 68%. Just by changing our food choices, we could be halfway to stopping climate change.

Climate change will mostly affect us young people because we will see its outcomes in our lifetime. Instead of being cynical, let's look for small, effective changes that we can make right now. Choosing more plant-based meals or snacks when possible is one of the easiest things we can do.

You can also find out which foods are especially harmful for to climate (hint: the farm animal that is worst for the climate rhymes with ‚Äòwow‚Äô).
Q10: Most pigs and chickens in the UK are kept indoors their whole lives and never see sunlight. I also see new plant-based products and restaurants appearing everywhere.  It looks like we'll have lots of options in the future!

Why not see if some of your favorite celebrities also eat plant-based?
Q8: Reducing how much meat, dairy, and sugary foods we eat can really help improve acne (up to 87% less acne in young people). Eating lots of vegetables and fruits also keeps our skin hydrated, protects us from getting sunburned, and even stops wrinkles.\n\nHaving clear, glowing skin might be as simple as just eating more veggies and fruits. When do you usually buy food during your day? Are there tasty plant-based options you could try the next time you have a choice?
Q9:
If everyone ate less animal foods, the CO2 from food production would drop by 68%. Just by changing our food choices, we could be halfway to stopping climate change.

Climate change will mostly affect us young people because we will see its outcomes in our lifetime. Instead of being cynical, let's look for small, effective changes that we can make right now. Choosing more plant-based meals or snacks when possible is one of the easiest things we can do.

You can also find out which foods are especially harmful for to climate (hint: the farm animal that is worst for the climate rhymes with ‚Äòwow‚Äô).
Q10: Most pigs and chickens in the UK are kept indoors their whole lives and never see sunlight. Animals that can't go outside are more stressed and, scientists say, much less happy.\n\nWe may not be able to change how animals are treated on these farms directly. But we can choose more vegetables and meat alternatives (like plant-based schnitzel, sausages, and burgers) instead of animal meat. This is the quickest way to help make animals' lives better.
Q11: Vegetables and fruits have helpful plant substances that support our brain health and help it work well. Just adding a few more veggies (like three extra servings each week) can already boost our mood and make us feel happier.\n\nThere's no limit to how many plants we can eat‚Äîit's all good for our brains! To start, you could challenge yourself, your friends, or your parents to have more plant-based meals on some days of the week (with an occasional cheat day here and there).
Q12: Animal farming is responsible for 80% of the loss of the Amazon rainforest because farmers need space for cattle and cattle food. Last year, the Amazon rainforest lost as many trees as there are in the UK and Ireland combined. Imagine if there were not a single tree left here!\n\nBy eating less meat (like choosing veggie burgers instead of regular burgers for lunch), we can make a difference without needing to change much. If you eat with others, you can also set an example and inspire your friends and classmates, to be more mindful about their food choices as well.

So stay tuned, as I will share lots of interesting science facts and give you tips for small changes that can make a big difference.
Q2: So fruits and veggies are filled with important nutrients like vitamins, minerals, and antioxidants that help our bodies fight diseases. So, reducing how much meat we eat can help save a lot of CO2, which causes climate change. For example, if we eat meat every other day instead of every day for a year, it saves as much CO2 as driving a car from London to China‚Ä¶ and back!

With small changes like this, everyone can help the environment and slow down climate change now without waiting for others! Let‚Äôs start small; for example, we can try to eat meat only once a day, instead of having it at breakfast, lunch, and dinner.
Q4:
More than 70% of farm animals in the UK are raised on factory farms to keep animal products cheap. So on these farms, a chicken has only about the space of a laptop, so hardly any room to move. It's like living under a staircase, like Harry Potter, for your whole life. 

But factory farms keep going because people buy their products. So by choosing to eat less meat or plant-based meats when we can, we can send a message to these farms to make better living conditions for their animals.

Q1:
Hello! I‚Äôm Sasha, nice to meet you! Over the next two weeks, I will explore healthy and sustainable eating with you.

A year ago, I started eating more plant-based foods and learned a lot along the way. It‚Äôs not about being perfect; I don‚Äôt think we all need to go completely vegan. However, being a bit mindful of how much animal food we eat and drink can be good for our health and the planet.

Stay tuned, as I will share lots of interesting science facts and give you tips for small changes that can make a big difference.
Q2: Fruits and vegetables are filled with important nutrients like vitamins, minerals, and antioxidants that help our bodies fight diseases. For instance, people who eat mostly plant foods were 39% less likely to get Covid and have fewer hospital visits overall.\n\nEvery time we buy food ourselves, we get to decide what goes into our bodies. To make it more fun, you could also talk with your friends during lunch and try out some plant-based foods together.
Q3: Reducing how much meat we eat can help save a lot of CO2, which causes climate change. For example, if we eat meat every other day instead of every day for a year, it saves as much CO2 as driving a car from London to China‚Ä¶ and back!\n\nWith small changes like this, everyone can help the environment and slow down climate change now without waiting for others! Let‚Äôs start small;  for example, we can try to eat meat only once a day, instead of having it at breakfast, lunch, and dinner.
Q4: More than 70% of farm animals in the UK are raised on factory farms to keep animal products cheap. On these farms, a chicken has only about the space of a laptop, so there's hardly any room to move. It's like living under a staircase, like Harry Potter, for your whole life.\n\nFactory farms keep going because people buy their products. By choosing to eat less meat or plant-based meats when we can, we can send a message to these farms to make better living conditions for their animals.
Q5: Fiber is really important for keeping our stomachs healthy, and it's only found in plants, not in animal foods. When we have enough fiber in our meals, we stay full for longer and have more energy throughout the school day, avoiding that tired feeling after lunch.\n\nChanging our habits, like what we eat, can be tricky at first. An easy way to start could be to try more plant-based lunches at school to feel more energetic and ready for the afternoon.
Q6: 80% of young people believe that living sustainably is very important for their happiness. Q9:
If everyone ate less animal foods, the CO2 from food production would drop by 68%. Just by changing our food choices, we could be halfway to stopping climate change.

Climate change will mostly affect us young people because we will see its outcomes in our lifetime. Instead of being cynical, let's look for small, effective changes that we can make right now. Choosing more plant-based meals or snacks when possible is one of the easiest things we can do.

Q10: Most pigs and chickens in the UK are kept indoors their whole lives and never see sunlight. Animals that can't go outside are more stressed and, scientists say, much less happy.\n\nWe may not be able to change how animals are treated on these farms directly. But we can choose more vegetables and meat alternatives (like plant-based schnitzel, sausages, and burgers) instead of animal meat. This is the quickest way to help make animals' lives better.

I'm excited to see how more people are choosing plant-based eating. Some of my favourite celebrities eat vegan, like Lewis Hamilton, Billie Eilish, and Ariana Grande. Others, like Harry Styles and Lionel Messi, avoid animal products for the most part.

I also see new plant-based products and restaurants appearing everywhere.  It looks like we'll have lots of options in the future!

Why not see if some of your favorite celebrities also eat plant-based?
Q8: Reducing how much meat, dairy, and sugary foods we eat can really help improve acne (up to 87% less acne in young people). Eating lots of vegetables and fruits also keeps our skin hydrated, protects us from getting sunburned, and even stops wrinkles.\n\nHaving clear, glowing skin might be as simple as just eating more veggies and fruits. When do you usually buy food during your day? Are there tasty plant-based options you could try the next time you have a choice?
Q9:
If everyone ate less animal foods, the CO2 from food production would drop by 68%. Just by changing our food choices, we could be halfway to stopping climate change.

Climate change will mostly affect us young people because we will see its outcomes in our lifetime. Instead of being cynical, let's look for small, effective changes that we can make right now. Choosing more plant-based meals or snacks when possible is one of the easiest things we can do.

You can also find out which foods are especially harmful for to climate (hint: the farm animal that is worst for the climate rhymes with ‚Äòwow‚Äô).
Q10: Most pigs and chickens in the UK are kept indoors their whole lives and never see sunlight. Animals that can't go outside are more stressed and, scientists say, much less happy.\n\nWe may not be able to change how animals are treated on these farms directly. But we can choose more vegetables and meat alternatives (like plant-based schnitzel, sausages, and burgers) instead of animal meat. This is the quickest way to help make animals' lives better.
Q11: Vegetables and fruits have helpful plant substances that support our brain health and help it work well. Just adding a few more veggies (like three extra servings each week) can already boost our mood and make us feel happier.\n\nThere's no limit to how many plants we can eat‚Äîit's all good for our brains! To start, you could challenge yourself, your friends, or your parents to have more plant-based meals on some days of the week (with an occasional cheat day here and there).
Q12: Animal farming is responsible for 80% of the loss of the Amazon rainforest because farmers need space for cattle and cattle food. Last year, the Amazon rainforest lost as many trees as there are in the UK and Ireland combined. Imagine if there were not a single tree left here!\n\nBy eating less meat (like choosing veggie burgers instead of regular burgers for lunch), we can make a difference without needing to change much. If you eat with others, you can also set an example and inspire your friends and classmates, to be more mindful about their food choices as well.

Stay tuned, cause I'll be sharing lots of interesting science facts and giving you tips for small changes that can make a big difference. üëå
Q2: Fruits and veggies are packed with important nutrients like vitamins, minerals, and antioxidants that help our bodies fight diseases. For instance, people who eat mostly plant foods were 39% less likely to get Covid and have fewer hospital visits overall. Every time we buy food ourselves, we get to decide what goes into our bodies. To make it more fun, you could also talk with your friends during lunch and try out some plant-based foods together.
Q3:
So, if we cut down on the meat we eat, we can save a lot of CO2, right? That's the stuff that causes climate change. Like, if we have meat every other day instead of every day for a year, it's like driving a car from London to China and back! 

With small changes like this, everyone can help the environment and slow down climate change now, no need to wait for others! Let's start small, yeah? Like, we can try having meat just once a day, instead of having it at breakfast, lunch, and dinner. What do you think?
Q4:
More than 70% of farm animals in the UK are raised on factory farms just to keep animal products cheap. On these farms, a chicken has only about the space of a laptop, so there's hardly any room to move. It's like living under a staircase, like Harry Potter, for your whole life, yeah?

Factory farms keep going because people buy their products. By choosing to eat less meat or plant-based meats when we can, we can send a message to these farms to make better living conditions for their animals. What about you?
Q5: Fiber is super important for keeping our stomachs healthy, and you can only find it in plants, not in animal foods. When we've got enough fiber in our meals, we stay full for way longer and have more energy throughout the school day, so we don't feel tired after lunch. Changing our habits, like what we eat, can be a bit tricky at first, right? But an easy way to start could be to try more plant-based lunches at school. That way, we'll feel more energetic and ready for the afternoon. What do you think?

Q4:

Q5:

Q9:

Q10:
So most pigs and chickens in the UK are kept indoors their whole lives and never see sunlight. Animals that can't go outside are more stressed and, scientists say, much less happy.

We may not be able to change how animals are treated on these farms directly. But we can choose more vegetables and meat alternatives (like plant-based schnitzel, sausages, and burgers) instead of animal meat. This is the quickest way to help make animals' lives better.

There's no limit to how many plants we can eat‚Äîit's all good for our brains! To start, you could challenge yourself, your friends, or your parents to have more plant-based meals on some days of the week (with an occasional cheat day here and there).

Q10: Yeah, most pigs and chickens in the UK are kept indoors their whole lives, never see sunlight. Animals that can't go outside are more stressed and, yeah scientists say, much less happy. We may not be able to change how animals are treated on these farms directly. But we can choose more vegetables and meat alternatives (like plant-based schnitzel, sausages, and burgers) instead of animal meat. This is the quickest way to help make animals' lives better.
Q11:
Yeah, veggies and fruits have stuff that's great for our brain, helps it work better. Just adding a few more veggies, like three extra each week, can boost our mood and make us happier.

No limit to how many plants we can eat, it's all good for our brains! You could challenge yourself, your friends, or your parents to have more plant-based meals on some days (with an occasional cheat day here and there).
Q12: Yeah, animal farming is responsible for 80% of the amazon rainforest loss, farmers need space for cattle and their food. Last year, the amazon lost as many trees as there are in the UK and Ireland combined. Imagine if there weren't a single tree left! By eating less meat, like choosing veggie burgers for lunch, we can make a difference without much change. If you eat with others, you can set an example and inspire your friends and classmates to be more mindful about their food choices too.

Q1:
Hey there! I‚Äôm Sasha, nice to meet you! Over the next couple of weeks, I'm going to be exploring healthy and sustainable eating with you. üçΩÔ∏è

So, about a year ago, I started eating more plant-based foods and I've learned a lot along the way. It's not about being perfect - I don't think we all need to go completely vegan. But, being a bit mindful of how much animal food we eat and drink can be good for our health and the planet, you know? üåç

Stay tuned, I'll be sharing lots of interesting science facts and giving you tips for small changes that can make a big difference. üëç
Q2: Honestly - fruits and veggies are packed with important nutrients like vitamins, minerals, and antioxidants that help our bodies fight diseases. It's been shown that people who eat mostly plant foods were 39% less likely to get Covid and have fewer hospital visits overall. Every time we buy food, we get to decide what goes into our bodies. To make it more fun, you could talk with your friends during lunch and try out some plant-based foods together.
Q3:
So, if we cut down on the meat we eat, it can really help save a lot of CO2 - you know, the stuff that causes climate change. Like, if we eat meat every other day instead of every day for a year, it saves as much CO2 as driving a car from London to China... and back! 

With small changes like this, everyone can do their bit for the environment and slow down climate change now, no need to wait for others! Let's start small, yeah? Like, we can try to have meat only once a day, instead of having it at breakfast, lunch, and dinner.
Q4:
So, more than 70% of farm animals in the UK are on factory farms, just to keep animal products cheap. It's like, a chicken only has about the space of a laptop, hardly any room to move. Imagine living under a staircase, like Harry Potter, for your whole life, right?

The thing is, these farms keep going because people buy their products. But if we choose to eat less meat or go for plant-based stuff when we can, we can send them a message to make better living conditions for the animals.
Q5:
Honestly, fiber is really important for keeping our stomachs healthy. You only find it in plants, not in animal foods. When we've got enough fiber in our meals, we stay full for longer and have more energy throughout the school day - no more of that tired feeling after lunch.

Changing habits, like what we eat, can be tricky at first, I get that. But an easy way to start could be to try more plant-based lunches at school. You'll feel more energetic and ready for the afternoon.
Q6:
