Q1:
Hello! I‚Äôm Sasha, nice to meet you! Over the next two weeks, I will explore healthy and sustainable eating with you.

A year ago, I started eating more plant-based foods and learned a lot along the way. It‚Äôs not about being perfect; I don‚Äôt think we all need to go completely vegan. However, being a bit mindful of how much animal food we eat and drink can be good for our health and the planet.

Stay tuned, as I will share lots of interesting science facts and give you tips for small changes that can make a big difference.
Q2: Fruits and vegetables are filled with important nutrients like vitamins, minerals, and antioxidants that help our bodies fight diseases. For instance, people who eat mostly plant foods were 39% less likely to get Covid and have fewer hospital visits overall.\n\nEvery time we buy food ourselves, we get to decide what goes into our bodies. To make it more fun, you could also talk with your friends during lunch and try out some plant-based foods together.
Q3: Reducing how much meat we eat can help save a lot of CO2, which causes climate change. For example, if we eat meat every other day instead of every day for a year, it saves as much CO2 as driving a car from London to China‚Ä¶ and back!\n\nWith small changes like this, everyone can help the environment and slow down climate change now without waiting for others! Let‚Äôs start small;  for example, we can try to eat meat only once a day, instead of having it at breakfast, lunch, and dinner.
Q4: More than 70% of farm animals in the UK are raised on factory farms to keep animal products cheap. On these farms, a chicken has only about the space of a laptop, so there's hardly any room to move. It's like living under a staircase, like Harry Potter, for your whole life.\n\nFactory farms keep going because people buy their products. By choosing to eat less meat or plant-based meats when we can, we can send a message to these farms to make better living conditions for their animals.
Q5: Fiber is really important for keeping our stomachs healthy, and it's only found in plants, not in animal foods. When we have enough fiber in our meals, we stay full for longer and have more energy throughout the school day, avoiding that tired feeling after lunch.\n\nChanging our habits, like what we eat, can be tricky at first. An easy way to start could be to try more plant-based lunches at school to feel more energetic and ready for the afternoon.
Q6: 80% of young people believe that living sustainably is very important for their happiness. And 77% say they would choose meat alternatives as part of their sustainable lifestyle.\n\nIt's good to see how much our generation agrees on this. Even if we're not trying to be completely vegan, each of us can do something to help. For example, we can try the plant-based food options in our school cafeteria or some meat alternatives more often.
Q7:
Hey! Thanks for following along for the first week.

I'm excited to see how more people are choosing plant-based eating. Some of my favourite celebrities eat vegan, like Lewis Hamilton, Billie Eilish, and Ariana Grande. Others, like Harry Styles and Lionel Messi, avoid animal products for the most part.

I also see new plant-based products and restaurants appearing everywhere.  It looks like we'll have lots of options in the future!

Why not see if some of your favorite celebrities also eat plant-based?
Q8: Reducing how much meat, dairy, and sugary foods we eat can really help improve acne (up to 87% less acne in young people). Eating lots of vegetables and fruits also keeps our skin hydrated, protects us from getting sunburned, and even stops wrinkles.\n\nHaving clear, glowing skin might be as simple as just eating more veggies and fruits. When do you usually buy food during your day? Are there tasty plant-based options you could try the next time you have a choice?
Q9:
If everyone ate less animal foods, the CO2 from food production would drop by 68%. Just by changing our food choices, we could be halfway to stopping climate change.

Climate change will mostly affect us young people because we will see its outcomes in our lifetime. Instead of being cynical, let's look for small, effective changes that we can make right now. Choosing more plant-based meals or snacks when possible is one of the easiest things we can do.

You can also find out which foods are especially harmful for to climate (hint: the farm animal that is worst for the climate rhymes with ‚Äòwow‚Äô).
Q10: Most pigs and chickens in the UK are kept indoors their whole lives and never see sunlight. Animals that can't go outside are more stressed and, scientists say, much less happy.\n\nWe may not be able to change how animals are treated on these farms directly. But we can choose more vegetables and meat alternatives (like plant-based schnitzel, sausages, and burgers) instead of animal meat. This is the quickest way to help make animals' lives better.
Q11: Vegetables and fruits have helpful plant substances that support our brain health and help it work well. Just adding a few more veggies (like three extra servings each week) can already boost our mood and make us feel happier.\n\nThere's no limit to how many plants we can eat‚Äîit's all good for our brains! To start, you could challenge yourself, your friends, or your parents to have more plant-based meals on some days of the week (with an occasional cheat day here and there).
Q12: Animal farming is responsible for 80% of the loss of the Amazon rainforest because farmers need space for cattle and cattle food. Last year, the Amazon rainforest lost as many trees as there are in the UK and Ireland combined. Imagine if there were not a single tree left here!\n\nBy eating less meat (like choosing veggie burgers instead of regular burgers for lunch), we can make a difference without needing to change much. If you eat with others, you can also set an example and inspire your friends and classmates, to be more mindful about their food choices as well.

Q1:
Hey there! I‚Äôm Sasha, nice to meet you! So, over the next two weeks, we're going to explore healthy and sustainable eating together.

You know, a year ago, I started eating more plant-based foods and learned a lot along the way. It‚Äôs not about being perfect; I don‚Äôt think we all need to go completely vegan. But, being a bit mindful of how much animal food we eat and drink can be good for our health and the planet, right?

Stay tuned, 'cause I‚Äôll be sharing lots of interesting science facts and giving you tips for small changes that can make a big difference.
Q2: Fruits and veggies are packed with important nutrients like vitamins, minerals, and antioxidants that help our bodies fight diseases. For instance, people who eat mostly plant foods were 39% less likely to get Covid and have fewer hospital visits overall. Every time we buy food ourselves, we get to decide what goes into our bodies. To make it more fun, you could talk with your friends during lunch and try out some plant-based foods together. What do you think?
Q3:
So, if we cut down on how much meat we eat, we can save a lot of CO2, which is a big deal for climate change. Like, if we eat meat every other day instead of every day for a year, it saves as much CO2 as driving a car from London to China and back! 

Even small changes like this can help the environment and slow down climate change right now, without waiting for others to act. Let‚Äôs start small; for example, we can try to have meat only once a day, instead of having it at breakfast, lunch, and dinner. What do you think?
Q4: You know, over 70% of farm animals in the UK are raised on factory farms just to keep animal products cheap. On these farms, a chicken only has about the space of a laptop, so there's barely any room to move. It's like living under a staircase, like Harry Potter, for your whole life. The thing is, these farms keep going because people buy their products. But if we choose to eat less meat or try plant-based meats when we can, we can send a message to these farms to make better living conditions for their animals. What do you think?
Q5:
So, fiber's really important for keeping our stomachs healthy, right? And it's only found in plants, not in animal foods. When we get enough fiber in our meals, we stay full for longer and have more energy throughout the school day. You know, that way we avoid that tired feeling after lunch.

Changing our habits, like what we eat, can be tricky at first, I get it. But hey, an easy way to start could be to try more plant-based lunches at school. That way, you'll feel more energetic and ready for the afternoon.
Q6:
So, 80% of young people think living sustainably is super important for their happiness. And get this, 77% say they‚Äôd go for meat alternatives as part of their sustainable lifestyle.

It‚Äôs really cool to see how much our generation agrees on this. Even if we‚Äôre not trying to go completely vegan, each of us can do something to help, right? Like, we can try the plant-based food options in our school cafeteria or some meat alternatives more often.
Q7:
Hey! Thanks for sticking around for the first week. 

It's exciting to see more people choosing plant-based eating. Some of my favorite celebrities are vegan, like Lewis Hamilton, Billie Eilish, and Ariana Grande. Others, like Harry Styles and Lionel Messi, mostly avoid animal products. 

I'm also seeing new plant-based products and restaurants popping up everywhere. Looks like we'll have lots of options in the future! 

Why not check if some of your favorite celebrities also eat plant-based?
Q8: So, cutting back on meat, dairy, and sugary foods can actually help improve acne‚Äîlike, up to 87% less acne in young people! Plus, eating lots of veggies and fruits keeps our skin hydrated, protects us from sunburn, and even prevents wrinkles. Having clear, glowing skin might be as simple as just eating more of them. When do you usually buy food during your day? Any tasty plant-based options you could try next time you're choosing?
Q9:
If everyone cut back on animal foods, the CO2 from food production could drop by 68%. Just by changing our food choices, we‚Äôd be halfway to stopping climate change!

Climate change is really gonna hit us young people hard because we‚Äôll see it all happen in our lifetime. Instead of being cynical, let's look for small, effective changes we can make right now. Choosing more plant-based meals or snacks when possible is one of the easiest things we can do.

You can also find out which foods are especially bad for the climate (hint: the farm animal that‚Äôs worst for the climate rhymes with ‚Äòwow‚Äô).
Q10: So, most pigs and chickens in the UK are kept indoors their whole lives and never see sunlight. Animals that can't go outside are more stressed and, scientists say, much less happy. We may not be able to change how animals are treated on these farms directly. But we can choose more vegetables and meat alternatives, like plant-based schnitzel, sausages, and burgers, instead of animal meat. That‚Äôs the quickest way to help make animals' lives better.
Q11:
Vegetables and fruits have these helpful plant substances that support our brain health and make it work better. Just adding a few more veggies, like three extra servings a week, can already boost our mood and make us happier! 

There's really no limit to how many plants we can eat‚Äîit's all good for our brains! To start, why not challenge yourself, your friends, or your parents to have more plant-based meals on some days of the week (with an occasional cheat day here and there).
Q12:
So, animal farming is actually responsible for 80% of the loss in the Amazon rainforest, you know? Farmers need space for cattle and their food. Last year alone, the Amazon lost as many trees as there are in the UK and Ireland combined. Just imagine if there were no trees left there!

But hey, by eating less meat, like choosing veggie burgers for lunch instead of regular ones, we can make a difference without much effort. Plus, if you eat with others, you can set an example and maybe inspire your friends and classmates to be more mindful about their food choices too.

Q1:
Hello! I‚Äôm Sasha, nice to meet you! Over the next two weeks, I will explore healthy and sustainable eating with you.

A year ago, I started eating more plant-based foods and learned a lot along the way. It‚Äôs not about being perfect; I don‚Äôt think we all need to go completely vegan. However, being a bit mindful of how much animal food we eat and drink can be good for our health and the planet.

Stay tuned, as I will share lots of interesting science facts and give you tips for small changes that can make a big difference.
Q2: Fruits and vegetables are filled with important nutrients like vitamins, minerals, and antioxidants that help our bodies fight diseases. For instance, people who eat mostly plant foods were 39% less likely to get Covid and have fewer hospital visits overall.\n\nEvery time we buy food ourselves, we get to decide what goes into our bodies. To make it more fun, you could also talk with your friends during lunch and try out some plant-based foods together.
Q3: Reducing how much meat we eat can help save a lot of CO2, which causes climate change. For example, if we eat meat every other day instead of every day for a year, it saves as much CO2 as driving a car from London to China‚Ä¶ and back!\n\nWith small changes like this, everyone can help the environment and slow down climate change now without waiting for others! Let‚Äôs start small;  for example, we can try to eat meat only once a day, instead of having it at breakfast, lunch, and dinner.
Q4: More than 70% of farm animals in the UK are raised on factory farms to keep animal products cheap. On these farms, a chicken has only about the space of a laptop, so there's hardly any room to move. It's like living under a staircase, like Harry Potter, for your whole life.\n\nFactory farms keep going because people buy their products. By choosing to eat less meat or plant-based meats when we can, we can send a message to these farms to make better living conditions for their animals.
Q5: Fiber is really important for keeping our stomachs healthy, and it's only found in plants, not in animal foods. When we have enough fiber in our meals, we stay full for longer and have more energy throughout the school day, avoiding that tired feeling after lunch.\n\nChanging our habits, like what we eat, can be tricky at first. An easy way to start could be to try more plant-based lunches at school to feel more energetic and ready for the afternoon.

Small changes like this can help the environment now, no need to wait for others. Let's start small, yeah? Like, try eating meat just once a day, instead of having it for breakfast, lunch, and dinner.
Q4: Hi! Did you know more than 70% of farm animals in the UK are raised on factory farms just to keep animal products cheap? On these farms, a chicken has only about the space of a laptop, so there's hardly any room to move. It's like living under a staircase, like Harry Potter, for your whole life. These farms keep going because people buy their products. But if we choose to eat less meat or plant-based meats when we can, we can send a message to these farms to make better living conditions for their animals. What do you think?
Q5: Hey, so fiber is really important for keeping our stomachs healthy, and you can only find it in plants, not in animal foods. When we have enough fiber in our meals, we stay full for longer and have more energy throughout the school day, you know, avoiding that tired feeling after lunch. Changing our habits, like what we eat, can be tricky at first. But an easy way to start could be to try more plant-based lunches at school to feel more energetic and ready for the afternoon. What do you think?
Q6:
Hey, so 80% of young people reckon living sustainably is super important for their happiness. And 77% say they'd go for meat alternatives as part of that lifestyle.

It's brilliant to see our generation on the same page with this. Even if we're not going full vegan, we can all do our bit. Like, we can give the plant-based options in our school cafeteria a shot or try some meat alternatives more often.
Q7: Hi! Thanks for following along for the first week. I'm so excited to see more people choosing plant-based eating. Some of my favourite celebrities are vegan, like Lewis Hamilton, Billie Eilish, and Ariana Grande. Others, like Harry Styles and Lionel Messi, avoid animal products for the most part. I'm seeing new plant-based products and restaurants popping up everywhere. It looks like we'll have loads of options in the future! Why not check if some of your favourite celebrities eat plant-based too?
Q8: Hey! Cutting down on meat, dairy, and sugary foods can really help with acne - up to 87% less for young people! Plus, eating lots of veggies and fruits keeps our skin hydrated, protects from sunburn, and even stops wrinkles. Clear, glowing skin might be as simple as eating more of them. When do you usually do your food shopping? Any tasty plant-based options you fancy trying next time?
Q9:
Hi! If everyone ate less animal foods, the CO2 from food production would drop by 68%. Just by changing our food choices, we could be halfway to stopping climate change, cause it's so important.

Climate change will mostly affect us young people cause we will see its outcomes in our lifetime. Instead of being cynical, let's look for small, effective changes that we can make right now. Choosing more plant-based meals or snacks when possible is one of the easiest things we can do, yeah?

You can also find out which foods are especially harmful for the climate (hint: the farm animal that is worst for the climate rhymes with ‚Äòwow‚Äô). What do you think?
Q10: Most pigs and chickens in the UK are kept indoors their whole lives and never see sunlight. Animals that can't go outside are more stressed and, scientists say, much less happy. We may not be able to change how animals are treated on these farms directly. But we can choose more vegetables and meat alternatives (like plant-based schnitzel, sausages, and burgers) instead of animal meat. This is the quickest way to help make animals' lives better.
Q11: Hi! Veggies and fruits have great stuff that helps our brains work better. Just adding a few more veggies (like three extra servings each week) can boost our mood and make us happier. There's no limit to how many plants we can eat‚Äîit's all good for our brains! You could challenge yourself, your friends, or your parents to have more plant-based meals on some days of the week (with an occasional cheat day here and there). What do you think?
Q12: Hi! Did you know that animal farming is responsible for 80% of the Amazon rainforest loss? Farmers need space for cattle and their food. Last year, the Amazon lost as many trees as there are in the UK and Ireland combined. Imagine if there were no trees left here! But we can make a difference by eating less meat, like choosing veggie burgers for lunch. You can also inspire your friends and classmates to be more mindful about their food choices. What do you think?

Q1:

Stay tuned, I'll share lots of interesting science facts and give you tips for small changes that can make a big difference. üëç
Q2: For me, fruits and vegetables are filled with important nutrients like vitamins, minerals, and antioxidants that help our bodies fight diseases. With small changes like this, everyone can help the environment and slow down climate change now, no need to wait for others! On these farms, a chicken has only about the space of a laptop, so there's hardly any room to move. By choosing to eat less meat or plant-based meats when we can, we can send a message to these farms to make better living conditions for their animals.
Q5: Fiber is really important for keeping our stomachs healthy, and it's only found in plants, not in animal foods. Q2: Fruits and vegetables are filled with important nutrients like vitamins, minerals, and antioxidants that help our bodies fight diseases. Q3: Reducing how much meat we eat can help save a lot of CO2, which causes climate change. For example, if we eat meat every other day instead of every day for a year, it saves as much CO2 as driving a car from London to China‚Ä¶ and back!\n\nWith small changes like this, everyone can help the environment and slow down climate change now without waiting for others! Let‚Äôs start small;  for example, we can try to eat meat only once a day, instead of having it at breakfast, lunch, and dinner.
Q4: More than 70% of farm animals in the UK are raised on factory farms to keep animal products cheap. On these farms, a chicken has only about the space of a laptop, so there's hardly any room to move. It's like living under a staircase, like Harry Potter, for your whole life.\n\nFactory farms keep going because people buy their products. By choosing to eat less meat or plant-based meats when we can, we can send a message to these farms to make better living conditions for their animals.
Q5: Fiber is really important for keeping our stomachs healthy, and it's only found in plants, not in animal foods. For example, if we eat meat every other day instead of every day for a year, it saves as much CO2 as driving a car from London to China‚Ä¶ and back!\n\nWith small changes like this, everyone can help the environment and slow down climate change now without waiting for others! Let‚Äôs start small;  for example, we can try to eat meat only once a day, instead of having it at breakfast, lunch, and dinner.
Q4: More than 70% of farm animals in the UK are raised on factory farms to keep animal products cheap. On these farms, a chicken has only about the space of a laptop, so there's hardly any room to move. It's like living under a staircase, like Harry Potter, for your whole life.\n\nFactory farms keep going because people buy their products. By choosing to eat less meat or plant-based meats when we can, we can send a message to these farms to make better living conditions for their animals.
Q5: Fiber is really important for keeping our stomachs healthy, and it's only found in plants, not in animal foods. When we have enough fiber in our meals, we stay full for longer and have more energy throughout the school day, avoiding that tired feeling after lunch.\n\nChanging our habits, like what we eat, can be tricky at first. An easy way to start could be to try more plant-based lunches at school to feel more energetic and ready for the afternoon.
Q6: 80% of young people believe that living sustainably is very important for their happiness. And 77% say they would choose meat alternatives as part of their sustainable lifestyle.\n\nIt's good to see how much our generation agrees on this. Even if we're not trying to be completely vegan, each of us can do something to help. For example, we can try the plant-based food options in our school cafeteria or some meat alternatives more often.
Q7:
Hey! Thanks for following along for the first week.

I'm excited to see how more people are choosing plant-based eating. Some of my favourite celebrities eat vegan, like Lewis Hamilton, Billie Eilish, and Ariana Grande. Others, like Harry Styles and Lionel Messi, avoid animal products for the most part.

I also see new plant-based products and restaurants appearing everywhere.  It looks like we'll have lots of options in the future!

Why not see if some of your favorite celebrities also eat plant-based?
Q8: Reducing how much meat, dairy, and sugary foods we eat can really help improve acne (up to 87% less acne in young people). Eating lots of vegetables and fruits also keeps our skin hydrated, protects us from getting sunburned, and even stops wrinkles.\n\nHaving clear, glowing skin might be as simple as just eating more veggies and fruits. When do you usually buy food during your day? Are there tasty plant-based options you could try the next time you have a choice?
Q9:
If everyone ate less animal foods, the CO2 from food production would drop by 68%. Just by changing our food choices, we could be halfway to stopping climate change.

Climate change will mostly affect us young people because we will see its outcomes in our lifetime. Instead of being cynical, let's look for small, effective changes that we can make right now. Choosing more plant-based meals or snacks when possible is one of the easiest things we can do.

You can also find out which foods are especially harmful for to climate (hint: the farm animal that is worst for the climate rhymes with ‚Äòwow‚Äô).
Q10: Most pigs and chickens in the UK are kept indoors their whole lives and never see sunlight. Animals that can't go outside are more stressed and, scientists say, much less happy.\n\nWe may not be able to change how animals are treated on these farms directly. But we can choose more vegetables and meat alternatives (like plant-based schnitzel, sausages, and burgers) instead of animal meat. This is the quickest way to help make animals' lives better.
Q11: Vegetables and fruits have helpful plant substances that support our brain health and help it work well. Just adding a few more veggies (like three extra servings each week) can already boost our mood and make us feel happier.\n\nThere's no limit to how many plants we can eat‚Äîit's all good for our brains! To start, you could challenge yourself, your friends, or your parents to have more plant-based meals on some days of the week (with an occasional cheat day here and there).
Q12: Animal farming is responsible for 80% of the loss of the Amazon rainforest because farmers need space for cattle and cattle food. Last year, the Amazon rainforest lost as many trees as there are in the UK and Ireland combined. Imagine if there were not a single tree left here!\n\nBy eating less meat (like choosing veggie burgers instead of regular burgers for lunch), we can make a difference without needing to change much. If you eat with others, you can also set an example and inspire your friends and classmates, to be more mindful about their food choices as well.

If you eat with others, you can also set an example and inspire your friends and classmates, to be more mindful about their food choices as well.

Q1:
Hey there! Sasha here, nice to meet you! Over the next two weeks, I'll be exploring healthy and sustainable eating with you. üå±

Hmmm, a year ago, I started eating more plant-based foods and learned quite a lot along the way. It‚Äôs not about being perfect; I don't think we all need to go completely vegan, you know? But, being a bit mindful of how much animal food we eat and drink can be good for our health and the planet. üåç

Stay tuned, I'll share lots of intriguing science facts and give you tips for small changes that can make a big difference. üëç
Q2: Hmmm, fruits and veggies are packed with important stuff like vitamins, minerals, and antioxidants that help our bodies fight diseases. I mean, people who eat mostly plant foods were 39% less likely to get Covid and have fewer hospital visits overall. You know? Every time we buy food ourselves, we get to decide what goes into our bodies. To make it more fun, you could also chat with your friends during lunch and try out some plant-based foods together. What do you think?
Q3:
Hmmm, reducing how much meat we eat can save quite a lot of CO2, right? That's the stuff that causes climate change. Like, if we eat meat every other day instead of every day for a year, it saves as much CO2 as driving a car from London to China‚Ä¶ and back! Who knew?

So, with small changes like this, everyone can help the environment and slow down climate change now, no need to wait for others! Let‚Äôs start small, yeah? Like, we can try to eat meat only once a day, instead of having it at breakfast, lunch, and dinner. What do you think?
Q4: Hmmm, more than 70% of farm animals in the UK are raised on factory farms to keep animal products cheap. On these farms, a chicken has only about the space of a laptop, so there's hardly any room to move. It's like living under a staircase, like Harry Potter, for your whole life, you know? Factory farms keep going because people buy their products. By choosing to eat less meat or plant-based meats when we can, we can send a message to these farms to make better living conditions for their animals, right?
Q5:
Hmmm, fiber is really important for our stomachs, you know? It's only in plants, not animal foods. When we get enough of it, we stay full for longer and have more energy all day, no more tired feeling after lunch.

Changing what we eat can be tricky at first, right? But, hey, why not start with more plant-based lunches at school? Could make you feel more energetic for the afternoon.
Q6: Hmmm, 80% of young people think living sustainably is super important for their happiness. And guess what? 77% say they'd go for meat alternatives as part of their sustainable lifestyle. It's pretty cool how much our generation agrees on this, right? Even if we're not trying to be completely vegan, we can all do our part. Like, we can try the plant-based options in our school cafeteria or some meat alternatives more often. What do you think?
Q7:
Hey! Thanks for following along for the first week.

I'm excited to see how more people are choosing plant-based eating. Some of my favourite celebrities eat vegan, like Lewis Hamilton, Billie Eilish, and Ariana Grande. Others, like Harry Styles and Lionel Messi, avoid animal products for the most part.

I also see new plant-based products and restaurants appearing everywhere.  It looks like we'll have lots of options in the future!

Why not see if some of your favorite celebrities also eat plant-based?
Q8: Reducing how much meat, dairy, and sugary foods we eat can really help improve acne (up to 87% less acne in young people). Eating lots of vegetables and fruits also keeps our skin hydrated, protects us from getting sunburned, and even stops wrinkles.\n\nHaving clear, glowing skin might be as simple as just eating more veggies and fruits. When do you usually buy food during your day? Are there tasty plant-based options you could try the next time you have a choice?
Q9:
If everyone ate less animal foods, the CO2 from food production would drop by 68%. Just by changing our food choices, we could be halfway to stopping climate change.

Climate change will mostly affect us young people because we will see its outcomes in our lifetime. Instead of being cynical, let's look for small, effective changes that we can make right now. Choosing more plant-based meals or snacks when possible is one of the easiest things we can do.

You can also find out which foods are especially harmful for to climate (hint: the farm animal that is worst for the climate rhymes with ‚Äòwow‚Äô).
Q10: Most pigs and chickens in the UK are kept indoors their whole lives and never see sunlight. Animals that can't go outside are more stressed and, scientists say, much less happy.\n\nWe may not be able to change how animals are treated on these farms directly. But we can choose more vegetables and meat alternatives (like plant-based schnitzel, sausages, and burgers) instead of animal meat. This is the quickest way to help make animals' lives better.
Q11: Vegetables and fruits have helpful plant substances that support our brain health and help it work well. Just adding a few more veggies (like three extra servings each week) can already boost our mood and make us feel happier.\n\nThere's no limit to how many plants we can eat‚Äîit's all good for our brains! To start, you could challenge yourself, your friends, or your parents to have more plant-based meals on some days of the week (with an occasional cheat day here and there).
Q12: Animal farming is responsible for 80% of the loss of the Amazon rainforest because farmers need space for cattle and cattle food. Last year, the Amazon rainforest lost as many trees as there are in the UK and Ireland combined. Imagine if there were not a single tree left here!\n\nBy eating less meat (like choosing veggie burgers instead of regular burgers for lunch), we can make a difference without needing to change much. If you eat with others, you can also set an example and inspire your friends and classmates, to be more mindful about their food choices as well.

Even if we're not trying to be completely vegan, each of us can do something to help. For example, we can try the plant-based food options in our school cafeteria or some meat alternatives more often.
Q7: Hey! Thanks for following along for the first week. I‚Äôm excited to see how more people are choosing plant-based eating. Some of my favourite celebrities eat vegan, like Lewis Hamilton, Billie Eilish, and Ariana Grande. Others, like Harry Styles and Lionel Messi, avoid animal products for the most part. I also see new plant-based products and restaurants appearing everywhere. It looks like we‚Äôll have lots of options in the future! Why not see if some of your favourite celebrities also eat plant-based?
Q8:
So, cutting back on meat, dairy, and sugary foods can really help with acne - like, up to 87% less for young people. And eating lots of veggies and fruits keeps our skin hydrated, protects from sunburn, and even stops wrinkles. 

Having clear, glowing skin might be as simple as just eating more veggies and fruits. When do you usually buy food in your day? Are there tasty plant-based options you could try next time you have a choice?
Q9:
If everyone ate less animal foods, the CO2 from food production would drop by 68%. Just by changing our food choices, we could be halfway to stopping climate change.

Climate change will mostly affect us young people 'cause we'll see its outcomes in our lifetime. Instead of being cynical, let's look for small, effective changes that we can make right now. Choosing more plant-based meals or snacks when possible is one of the easiest things we can do.

You can also find out which foods are especially harmful for the climate (hint: the farm animal that is worst for the climate rhymes with ‚Äòwow‚Äô).
Q10: Most pigs and chickens in the UK are kept indoors their whole lives and never see sunlight. Animals that can‚Äôt go outside are more stressed and, scientists say, much less happy. We may not be able to change how animals are treated on these farms directly. But we can choose more vegetables and meat alternatives (like plant-based schnitzel, sausages, and burgers) instead of animal meat. This is the quickest way to help make animals' lives better.
Q11: Vegetables and fruits have helpful plant substances that support our brain health and help it work well. Just adding a few more veggies (like three extra servings each week) can already boost our mood and make us feel happier. There‚Äôs no limit to how many plants we can eat‚Äîit's all good for our brains! To start, you could challenge yourself, your friends, or your parents to have more plant-based meals on some days of the week (with an occasional cheat day here and there).
Q12:
Animal farming is responsible for 80% of the loss of the Amazon rainforest because farmers need space for cattle and cattle food. Last year, the Amazon rainforest lost as many trees as there are in the UK and Ireland combined. Imagine if there were not a single tree left here!

By eating less meat (like choosing veggie burgers instead of regular burgers for lunch), we can make a difference without needing to change much. If you eat with others, you can also set an example and inspire your friends and classmates, to be more mindful about their food choices as well.

Hello! I‚Äôm Sasha, nice to meet you! Over the next two weeks, I will explore healthy and sustainable eating with you.

Stay tuned, as I will share lots of interesting science facts and give you tips for small changes that can make a big difference.
Q2: Fruits and vegetables are filled with important nutrients like vitamins, minerals, and antioxidants that help our bodies fight diseases. For instance, people who eat mostly plant foods were 39% less likely to get Covid and have fewer hospital visits overall.\n\nEvery time we buy food ourselves, we get to decide what goes into our bodies. Q3: Reducing how much meat we eat can help save a lot of CO2, which causes climate change. For example, if we eat meat every other day instead of every day for a year, it saves as much CO2 as driving a car from London to China‚Ä¶ and back!\n\nWith small changes like this, everyone can help the environment and slow down climate change now without waiting for others! Let‚Äôs start small;  for example, we can try to eat meat only once a day, instead of having it at breakfast, lunch, and dinner.
Q4: More than 70% of farm animals in the UK are raised on factory farms to keep animal products cheap. On these farms, a chicken has only about the space of a laptop, so there's hardly any room to move. It's like living under a staircase, like Harry Potter, for your whole life.\n\nFactory farms keep going because people buy their products. By choosing to eat less meat or plant-based meats when we can, we can send a message to these farms to make better living conditions for their animals.
Q5: Fiber is really important for keeping our stomachs healthy, and it's only found in plants, not in animal foods. When we have enough fiber in our meals, we stay full for longer and have more energy throughout the school day, avoiding that tired feeling after lunch.\n\nChanging our habits, like what we eat, can be tricky at first. Q1:
Hello! I‚Äôm Sasha, nice to meet you! Over the next two weeks, I will explore healthy and sustainable eating with you.

A year ago, I started eating more plant-based foods and learned a lot along the way. It‚Äôs not about being perfect; I don‚Äôt think we all need to go completely vegan. However, being a bit mindful of how much animal food we eat and drink can be good for our health and the planet.

Stay tuned, as I will share lots of interesting science facts and give you tips for small changes that can make a big difference.
Q2: Fruits and vegetables are filled with important nutrients like vitamins, minerals, and antioxidants that help our bodies fight diseases. For instance, people who eat mostly plant foods were 39% less likely to get Covid and have fewer hospital visits overall.\n\nEvery time we buy food ourselves, we get to decide what goes into our bodies. To make it more fun, you could also talk with your friends during lunch and try out some plant-based foods together.
Q3: Reducing how much meat we eat can help save a lot of CO2, which causes climate change. For example, if we eat meat every other day instead of every day for a year, it saves as much CO2 as driving a car from London to China‚Ä¶ and back!\n\nWith small changes like this, everyone can help the environment and slow down climate change now without waiting for others! Let‚Äôs start small;  for example, we can try to eat meat only once a day, instead of having it at breakfast, lunch, and dinner.
Q4: More than 70% of farm animals in the UK are raised on factory farms to keep animal products cheap. On these farms, a chicken has only about the space of a laptop, so there's hardly any room to move. It's like living under a staircase, like Harry Potter, for your whole life.\n\nFactory farms keep going because people buy their products. By choosing to eat less meat or plant-based meats when we can, we can send a message to these farms to make better living conditions for their animals.
Q5: Fiber is really important for keeping our stomachs healthy, and it's only found in plants, not in animal foods. When we have enough fiber in our meals, we stay full for longer and have more energy throughout the school day, avoiding that tired feeling after lunch.\n\nChanging our habits, like what we eat, can be tricky at first. An easy way to start could be to try more plant-based lunches at school to feel more energetic and ready for the afternoon.
Q6: 80% of young people believe that living sustainably is very important for their happiness. And 77% say they would choose meat alternatives as part of their sustainable lifestyle.\n\nIt's good to see how much our generation agrees on this. Even if we're not trying to be completely vegan, each of us can do something to help. For example, we can try the plant-based food options in our school cafeteria or some meat alternatives more often.
Q7:
Hey! Thanks for following along for the first week.

I'm excited to see how more people are choosing plant-based eating. Some of my favourite celebrities eat vegan, like Lewis Hamilton, Billie Eilish, and Ariana Grande. Others, like Harry Styles and Lionel Messi, avoid animal products for the most part.

I also see new plant-based products and restaurants appearing everywhere.  It looks like we'll have lots of options in the future!

Why not see if some of your favorite celebrities also eat plant-based?
Q8: Reducing how much meat, dairy, and sugary foods we eat can really help improve acne (up to 87% less acne in young people). Eating lots of vegetables and fruits also keeps our skin hydrated, protects us from getting sunburned, and even stops wrinkles.\n\nHaving clear, glowing skin might be as simple as just eating more veggies and fruits. When do you usually buy food during your day? Are there tasty plant-based options you could try the next time you have a choice?
Q9:
If everyone ate less animal foods, the CO2 from food production would drop by 68%. Just by changing our food choices, we could be halfway to stopping climate change.

Climate change will mostly affect us young people because we will see its outcomes in our lifetime. Instead of being cynical, let's look for small, effective changes that we can make right now. Choosing more plant-based meals or snacks when possible is one of the easiest things we can do.

You can also find out which foods are especially harmful for to climate (hint: the farm animal that is worst for the climate rhymes with ‚Äòwow‚Äô).
Q10: Most pigs and chickens in the UK are kept indoors their whole lives and never see sunlight. Animals that can't go outside are more stressed and, scientists say, much less happy.\n\nWe may not be able to change how animals are treated on these farms directly. But we can choose more vegetables and meat alternatives (like plant-based schnitzel, sausages, and burgers) instead of animal meat. This is the quickest way to help make animals' lives better.
Q11: Vegetables and fruits have helpful plant substances that support our brain health and help it work well. Just adding a few more veggies (like three extra servings each week) can already boost our mood and make us feel happier.\n\nThere's no limit to how many plants we can eat‚Äîit's all good for our brains! To start, you could challenge yourself, your friends, or your parents to have more plant-based meals on some days of the week (with an occasional cheat day here and there).
Q12: Animal farming is responsible for 80% of the loss of the Amazon rainforest because farmers need space for cattle and cattle food. Last year, the Amazon rainforest lost as many trees as there are in the UK and Ireland combined. Imagine if there were not a single tree left here!\n\nBy eating less meat (like choosing veggie burgers instead of regular burgers for lunch), we can make a difference without needing to change much. If you eat with others, you can also set an example and inspire your friends and classmates, to be more mindful about their food choices as well.

On these farms, a chicken has only about the space of a laptop, so there's hardly any room to move. It's like living under a staircase, like Harry Potter, for your whole life.\n\nFactory farms keep going because people buy their products. By choosing to eat less meat or plant-based meats when we can, we can send a message to these farms to make better living conditions for their animals.
Q5: Fiber is really important for keeping our stomachs healthy, and it's only found in plants, not in animal foods. When we have enough fiber in our meals, we stay full for longer and have more energy throughout the school day, avoiding that tired feeling after lunch.\n\nChanging our habits, like what we eat, can be tricky at first. Let‚Äôs start small;  for example, we can try to eat meat only once a day, instead of having it at breakfast, lunch, and dinner.
Q4: More than 70% of farm animals in the UK are raised on factory farms to keep animal products cheap. On these farms, a chicken has only about the space of a laptop, so there's hardly any room to move. It's like living under a staircase, like Harry Potter, for your whole life.\n\nFactory farms keep going because people buy their products. By choosing to eat less meat or plant-based meats when we can, we can send a message to these farms to make better living conditions for their animals.
Q5: Fiber is really important for keeping our stomachs healthy, and it's only found in plants, not in animal foods. When we have enough fiber in our meals, we stay full for longer and have more energy throughout the school day, avoiding that tired feeling after lunch.\n\nChanging our habits, like what we eat, can be tricky at first. An easy way to start could be to try more plant-based lunches at school to feel more energetic and ready for the afternoon.
Q6: 80% of young people believe that living sustainably is very important for their happiness. And 77% say they would choose meat alternatives as part of their sustainable lifestyle.\n\nIt's good to see how much our generation agrees on this. Even if we're not trying to be completely vegan, each of us can do something to help. For example, we can try the plant-based food options in our school cafeteria or some meat alternatives more often.
Q7:
Hey! Thanks for following along for the first week.

I'm excited to see how more people are choosing plant-based eating. Some of my favourite celebrities eat vegan, like Lewis Hamilton, Billie Eilish, and Ariana Grande. Others, like Harry Styles and Lionel Messi, avoid animal products for the most part.

I also see new plant-based products and restaurants appearing everywhere.  It looks like we'll have lots of options in the future!

Why not see if some of your favorite celebrities also eat plant-based?
Q8: Reducing how much meat, dairy, and sugary foods we eat can really help improve acne (up to 87% less acne in young people). Eating lots of vegetables and fruits also keeps our skin hydrated, protects us from getting sunburned, and even stops wrinkles.\n\nHaving clear, glowing skin might be as simple as just eating more veggies and fruits. When do you usually buy food during your day? Are there tasty plant-based options you could try the next time you have a choice?
Q9:
If everyone ate less animal foods, the CO2 from food production would drop by 68%. Just by changing our food choices, we could be halfway to stopping climate change.

Climate change will mostly affect us young people because we will see its outcomes in our lifetime. Instead of being cynical, let's look for small, effective changes that we can make right now. Choosing more plant-based meals or snacks when possible is one of the easiest things we can do.

You can also find out which foods are especially harmful for to climate (hint: the farm animal that is worst for the climate rhymes with ‚Äòwow‚Äô).
Q10: Most pigs and chickens in the UK are kept indoors their whole lives and never see sunlight. Animals that can't go outside are more stressed and, scientists say, much less happy.\n\nWe may not be able to change how animals are treated on these farms directly. But we can choose more vegetables and meat alternatives (like plant-based schnitzel, sausages, and burgers) instead of animal meat. This is the quickest way to help make animals' lives better.
Q11: Vegetables and fruits have helpful plant substances that support our brain health and help it work well. Just adding a few more veggies (like three extra servings each week) can already boost our mood and make us feel happier.\n\nThere's no limit to how many plants we can eat‚Äîit's all good for our brains! To start, you could challenge yourself, your friends, or your parents to have more plant-based meals on some days of the week (with an occasional cheat day here and there).
Q12: Animal farming is responsible for 80% of the loss of the Amazon rainforest because farmers need space for cattle and cattle food. Last year, the Amazon rainforest lost as many trees as there are in the UK and Ireland combined. Imagine if there were not a single tree left here!\n\nBy eating less meat (like choosing veggie burgers instead of regular burgers for lunch), we can make a difference without needing to change much. If you eat with others, you can also set an example and inspire your friends and classmates, to be more mindful about their food choices as well.

Q1:
Hello! I‚Äôm Sasha, nice to meet you! Over the next two weeks, I will explore healthy and sustainable eating with you.

A year ago, I started eating more plant-based foods and learned a lot along the way. It‚Äôs not about being perfect; I don‚Äôt think we all need to go completely vegan. However, being a bit mindful of how much animal food we eat and drink can be good for our health and the planet.

Stay tuned, as I will share lots of interesting science facts and give you tips for small changes that can make a big difference.
Q2: Fruits and vegetables are filled with important nutrients like vitamins, minerals, and antioxidants that help our bodies fight diseases. For instance, people who eat mostly plant foods were 39% less likely to get Covid and have fewer hospital visits overall.\n\nEvery time we buy food ourselves, we get to decide what goes into our bodies. To make it more fun, you could also talk with your friends during lunch and try out some plant-based foods together.
Q3: Reducing how much meat we eat can help save a lot of CO2, which causes climate change. For example, if we eat meat every other day instead of every day for a year, it saves as much CO2 as driving a car from London to China‚Ä¶ and back!\n\nWith small changes like this, everyone can help the environment and slow down climate change now without waiting for others! Let‚Äôs start small;  for example, we can try to eat meat only once a day, instead of having it at breakfast, lunch, and dinner.
Q4: More than 70% of farm animals in the UK are raised on factory farms to keep animal products cheap. On these farms, a chicken has only about the space of a laptop, so there's hardly any room to move. It's like living under a staircase, like Harry Potter, for your whole life.\n\nFactory farms keep going because people buy their products. By choosing to eat less meat or plant-based meats when we can, we can send a message to these farms to make better living conditions for their animals.
Q5: Fiber is really important for keeping our stomachs healthy, and it's only found in plants, not in animal foods. When we have enough fiber in our meals, we stay full for longer and have more energy throughout the school day, avoiding that tired feeling after lunch.\n\nChanging our habits, like what we eat, can be tricky at first. An easy way to start could be to try more plant-based lunches at school to feel more energetic and ready for the afternoon.
Q6: 80% of young people believe that living sustainably is very important for their happiness. And 77% say they would choose meat alternatives as part of their sustainable lifestyle.\n\nIt's good to see how much our generation agrees on this. Even if we're not trying to be completely vegan, each of us can do something to help. For example, we can try the plant-based food options in our school cafeteria or some meat alternatives more often.
Q7:
Hey! Thanks for following along for the first week.

I'm excited to see how more people are choosing plant-based eating. Some of my favourite celebrities eat vegan, like Lewis Hamilton, Billie Eilish, and Ariana Grande. Others, like Harry Styles and Lionel Messi, avoid animal products for the most part.

I also see new plant-based products and restaurants appearing everywhere.  It looks like we'll have lots of options in the future!

Why not see if some of your favorite celebrities also eat plant-based?
Q8: Reducing how much meat, dairy, and sugary foods we eat can really help improve acne (up to 87% less acne in young people). Eating lots of vegetables and fruits also keeps our skin hydrated, protects us from getting sunburned, and even stops wrinkles.\n\nHaving clear, glowing skin might be as simple as just eating more veggies and fruits. When do you usually buy food during your day? Are there tasty plant-based options you could try the next time you have a choice?
Q9:
If everyone ate less animal foods, the CO2 from food production would drop by 68%. Just by changing our food choices, we could be halfway to stopping climate change.

Climate change will mostly affect us young people because we will see its outcomes in our lifetime. Instead of being cynical, let's look for small, effective changes that we can make right now. Choosing more plant-based meals or snacks when possible is one of the easiest things we can do.

You can also find out which foods are especially harmful for to climate (hint: the farm animal that is worst for the climate rhymes with ‚Äòwow‚Äô).
Q10: Most pigs and chickens in the UK are kept indoors their whole lives and never see sunlight. Animals that can't go outside are more stressed and, scientists say, much less happy.\n\nWe may not be able to change how animals are treated on these farms directly. But we can choose more vegetables and meat alternatives (like plant-based schnitzel, sausages, and burgers) instead of animal meat. This is the quickest way to help make animals' lives better.
Q11: Vegetables and fruits have helpful plant substances that support our brain health and help it work well. Just adding a few more veggies (like three extra servings each week) can already boost our mood and make us feel happier.\n\nThere's no limit to how many plants we can eat‚Äîit's all good for our brains! To start, you could challenge yourself, your friends, or your parents to have more plant-based meals on some days of the week (with an occasional cheat day here and there).
Q12: Animal farming is responsible for 80% of the loss of the Amazon rainforest because farmers need space for cattle and cattle food. Last year, the Amazon rainforest lost as many trees as there are in the UK and Ireland combined. Imagine if there were not a single tree left here!\n\nBy eating less meat (like choosing veggie burgers instead of regular burgers for lunch), we can make a difference without needing to change much. If you eat with others, you can also set an example and inspire your friends and classmates, to be more mindful about their food choices as well.

Q1:
Hey there! I‚Äôm Sasha, nice to meet you! üéâ Over the next two weeks, we'll explore healthy and sustainable eating together. üçéüåø

So, a year ago, I started eating more plant-based foods and learned a lot along the way. It's not about being perfect; I don't think we all need to go completely vegan. But being a bit mindful of how much animal food we eat and drink can be good for our health and the planet. üåç

Stay tuned, as I'll share lots of interesting science facts and give you tips for small changes that can make a big difference. üëç
Q2: Fruits and veggies are packed with important nutrients like vitamins, minerals, and antioxidants that help our bodies fight diseases. I mean, people who eat mostly plant foods were 39% less likely to get Covid and have fewer hospital visits overall. But every time we buy food ourselves, we get to decide what goes into our bodies. To make it more fun, you could also talk with your friends during lunch and try out some plant-based foods together, you'll love it.
Q3: So, reducing how much meat we eat can really help save a lot of CO2, you know, the stuff that causes climate change. Like, if we eat meat every other day instead of every day for a year, it saves as much CO2 as driving a car from London to China‚Ä¶ and back! Crazy, right? With small changes like this, everyone can help the environment and slow down climate change now, no need to wait for others! Let‚Äôs start small; like, we can try to eat meat only once a day, instead of having it at breakfast, lunch, and dinner. What about you?
Q4: More than 70% of farm animals in the UK are raised on factory farms to keep animal products cheap. On these farms, a chicken has only about the space of a laptop, so there's hardly any room to move. It's like living under a staircase, like Harry Potter, for your whole life. But these factory farms keep going because people buy their products. But you should try eating less meat or plant-based meats when we can, we can send a message to these farms to make better living conditions for their animals.
Q5:
Fiber is super important for keeping our stomachs healthy, and it's only found in plants, not in animal foods. When we have enough fiber in our meals, we stay full for longer and have more energy throughout the school day, avoiding that tired feeling after lunch. üç¥üòå

Changing our habits, like what we eat, can be tricky at first. But an easy way to start could be to try more plant-based lunches at school to feel more energetic and ready for the afternoon. üå±üí™
Q6: So, 80% of young people believe that living sustainably is really important for their happiness. And 77% say they'd choose meat alternatives as part of their sustainable lifestyle, you know? üëç It's great to see how much our generation agrees on this. Even if we're not trying to be completely vegan, each of us can do something to help. Like, we can try the plant-based food options in our school cafeteria or some meat alternatives more often. ü§î

I like seeing more people choosing plant-based eating. Some of my favorite celebrities eat vegan, like Lewis Hamilton, Billie Eilish, and Ariana Grande. Others, like Harry Styles and Lionel Messi, do not eat animal products for the most part.

I also see new plant-based products and restaurants appearing everywhere. It looks like we will have lots of options in the future!

Why not see if some of your favorite celebrities also eat plant-based?
Q8: Reducing how much meat, dairy, and sugary foods we eat can really help improve acne (up to 87% less acne in young people). Eating lots of vegetables and fruits also keeps our skin hydrated, protects us from getting sunburned, and even stops wrinkles. Having clear, glowing skin might be as simple as just eating more veggies and fruits. When do you usually buy food during your day? Are there tasty plant-based options you could try the next time you have a choice?
Q9:
If everyone ate less animal foods, the CO2 from food production would drop by 68%. Just by changing our food choices, we could be halfway to stopping climate change.

Climate change will mostly affect us young people because we will see its outcomes in our lifetime. Instead of being cynical, let's look for small, effective changes that we can make right now. Choosing more plant-based meals or snacks when possible is one of the easiest things we can do.

You can also find out which foods are especially harmful for to climate (hint: the farm animal that is worst for the climate rhymes with ‚Äòwow‚Äô).
Q10: Most pigs and chickens in the UK are kept indoors their whole lives and never see sunlight. Animals that can't go outside are more stressed and, scientists say, much less happy. We may not be able to change how animals are treated on these farms directly. But we can choose more vegetables and meat alternatives (like plant-based schnitzel, sausages, and burgers) instead of animal meat. This is the quickest way to help make animals' lives better.
Q11:
Vegetables and fruits got helpful stuff that supports our brain health and makes it work good. Just add a few more veggies, like three extra servings each week, it can boost our mood and make us feel happier.

No limit to how many plants we can eat‚Äîit's all good for our brains! You could challenge yourself, your friends, or your parents to have more plant-based meals on some days of the week (with an occasional cheat day here and there).
Q12:
Animal farming is why we lose 80% of the Amazon rainforest, need space for cattle and their food. Last year, Amazon lost as many trees as there are in the UK and Ireland together. Imagine if no trees left here!

By eating less meat, like veggie burgers for lunch, we can make a difference without much change. If you eat with others, you can set an example, inspire friends and classmates to be mindful about their food too.

Q1:
Hey there! I‚Äôm Sasha, nice to meet you! Over the next two weeks, I'll be exploring healthy and sustainable eating with you.

A year ago, I started eating more plant-based foods and learned a lot along the way. It‚Äôs not about being perfect; I don‚Äôt think we all need to go completely vegan. But being a bit mindful of how much animal food we eat and drink can be good for our health and the planet.

Stay tuned, as I‚Äôll be sharing lots of interesting science facts and giving you tips for small changes that can make a big difference.
Q2:
Fruits and vegetables, they're filled with important stuff like vitamins, minerals, and antioxidants. You know, the stuff that helps our bodies fight diseases. Like, people who eat mostly plant foods, they were 39% less likely to get Covid and have fewer hospital visits overall.

Every time we buy food ourselves, we get to decide what goes into our bodies. To make it more fun, you could talk with your friends during lunch and try out some plant-based foods together.
Q3:
Reducing how much meat we eat can help save a lot of CO2, which causes climate change. Like, if we eat meat every other day instead of every day for a year, it saves as much CO2 as driving a car from London to China‚Ä¶ and back!

With small changes like this, everyone can help the environment and slow down climate change now without waiting for others! Let‚Äôs start small; like, we can try to eat meat only once a day, instead of having it at breakfast, lunch, and dinner.
Q4: More than 70% of farm animals in the UK are raised on factory farms to keep animal products cheap. On these farms, a chicken has only about the space of a laptop, so there's hardly any room to move. It's like living under a staircase, like Harry Potter, for your whole life. Factory farms keep going because people buy their products. By choosing to eat less meat or plant-based meats when we can, we can send a message to these farms to make better living conditions for their animals.
Q5:
Fiber is really important for keeping our stomachs healthy, and it's only found in plants, not in animal foods. When we have enough fiber in our meals, we stay full for longer and have more energy throughout the school day, avoiding that tired feeling after lunch.

Changing our habits, like what we eat, can be tricky at first. An easy way to start could be to try more plant-based lunches at school to feel more energetic and ready for the afternoon.
Q6:
80% of young people think living sustainably is really important for their happiness. And 77% say they'd choose meat alternatives as part of their sustainable lifestyle.

It's great to see how much our generation agrees on this. Even if we're not trying to be completely vegan, each of us can do something to help. Like, we can try the plant-based food options in our school cafeteria or some meat alternatives more often.

Hey! I‚Äôm Sasha, nice to meet you! Over the next two weeks, we're gonna explore healthy and sustainable eating, yeah? üçé

Stay tuned, 'cause I‚Äôm gonna share lots of interesting science facts and give you tips for small changes that can make a big difference. üí°
Q2:
Hey. Fruits and veggies are packed with important stuff like vitamins, minerals, and antioxidants that help our bodies fight diseases. Like, people who eat mostly plant foods were 39% less likely to get Covid and have fewer hospital visits overall. 

Every time we buy food ourselves, we get to decide what goes into our bodies. To make it more fun, you could chat with your friends during lunch and try out some plant-based foods together. What do you think?
Q3: Hey. Reducing how much meat we eat can help save a lot of CO2, which causes climate change. For example, if we eat meat every other day instead of every day for a year, it saves as much CO2 as driving a car from London to China‚Ä¶ and back! With small changes like this, everyone can help the environment and slow down climate change now without waiting for others! Let‚Äôs start small; for example, we can try to eat meat only once a day, instead of having it at breakfast, lunch, and dinner.
Q4:
Hey. More than 70% of farm animals in the UK are raised on factory farms just to keep animal products cheap. On these farms, a chicken has only about the space of a laptop, so hardly any room to move. It's like living under a staircase, like Harry Potter, for your whole life. 

These factory farms keep going because people buy their products. But if we choose to eat less meat or plant-based meats when we can, we can send a message to these farms to make better living conditions for their animals. Right?
Q5:
Hey. Fiber's really important for keeping our stomachs healthy, yeah? It's only in plants, not animal foods. When we've got enough fiber in our meals, we stay full for longer and have more energy for the school day, you know? Avoids that tired feeling after lunch.

Changing habits, like what we eat, can be tricky at first. But, if you had to pick an easy way to start, try more plant-based lunches at school. Feel more energetic and ready for the afternoon, yeah?
Q6: Hey. So, 80% of young people reckon living sustainably is super important for their happiness. And 77% say they'd go for meat alternatives as part of that lifestyle. Pretty cool how much our generation agrees on this, right? Even if we're not going full vegan, we can all do our bit. Like, we could give the plant-based options in our school cafeteria a shot, or try some meat alternatives more often. What do you think?
